When it comes to eco-consciousness, you guys completely missed the elephant in the room.  That elephant's name is Planned Obsolescence.  Apple designs their products to be obsolete within a period of time so users are required to get a new device.  That is not eco-friendly...I don't care how many solar panels that Apple has on their headquarters. And what about storage space as a matter of eco-consciousness?  With virtually every Android, you can pop in a microSD card and have plenty of storage for years.  However with an iPhone, you are limited to how much storage they put in the device.  Once the storage is full, it's time to upgrade your device.  Yes, there is the cloud...but both phones offer cloud services so you can't argue that "you get more storage if you use the cloud with your iPhone."  If you're out of mobile data or in  a coverage dead spot and don't have access to wifi, good luck using your cloud storage.

Ok... He uses the most superficial criteria without thinking about more practical issues concerning the two functional ones. You have as a criterion the camera, which in the apple is one and specific. Have Samsung represent all the androids they are like "state cities" Which means it's nothing specific. Therefore, the cameras differ from mobile to mobile and not from Android on iPhone. Correspondingly with the battery, but here I can say that Android superpowers against iOS, Because they know better to check their battery. You have the startup control from settings and id you root the phone then you will take full control of yoyr device. But, without root you are safe and you have enough control.   Source: android is based to linux. Linux is open sourse kernel , and allows their users complete control over them. The manufacturers of Android They limit liberties to ensure that the amateur - unaffiliated user will not damage the operating system. However, there are plenty of alternative settings, many of which are offered by external applications.  Applications: Huge variety with a lot of possibilities, joy on android. We are not limited to a specific source. On the contrary, we can get applications from the source we choose, even from browser. Beacuse apk files Only accessible to the user. Applications can be shared very easily and comfortably through this file.  File managing... Which exactly has a file manager in the Iphone?  Share: can iphones share files via bluetooth? I remember that something like this was never done, I hope they changed it now.  Customize: Androids, because they are open source, have the ability to have variety Not in "pictures" of course. I am referring to live wallpapers which are applied by various methods, the home screen which can be completely changed, correspondingly the keyboard,   Transfer files to windows pc via usb: Androids can do it without much trouble. Oh, as far as I know ios need program to do that, am a right?  Version of applications: Huge problem on iOS. On Android, if I don't like the latest version of an app, I have the right to keep the old one. To do this on iOS requires intervention from a computer.  So, the title android vs iphone is Very wrong. The correct title is here: What is better for you? A fixed experience or an experience of your own organization and freedom within your device? User of both worlds here: One thing regarding the Eco part, in my view, is, that a plus for the iPhone is that it seems to keep its value and operability for quite some time. Most of my Android phones become unusable after ~3 years. But a big minus that counteracts all the positive things regarding the eco part is Apple's hostile behavior in actively sabotaging every attempt to repair devices, blocking 3rd party repair-services, and making the devices unmaintainable overall - or if possible, making the official, proprietary repairs more expensive than new devices (hint to the Louis Rossman YT Channel). Plus, I often get the feeling that you pay the most by far for their devices, but they act like you do not really own them. Which is especially mind-blowing given the price.

The iPhone user experience can sometimes be frustrating due to certain design choices and functionality issues. For instance, adjusting GPS settings through the settings menu feels inconvenient. Additionally, Wi-Fi often remains active even when turned off, which can be confusing, especially when networks are recommended. The default keyboard is also slow, especially when typing characters like "Å±Ã¡Ã©ÃºÅ‘Ã³Ã¼Ã¶Ã­" which are frequently used in my language. In contrast, Samsung's keyboard learns user preferences over time, allowing for quicker and more accurate typing.  Signal strength is another concern, as the iPhone 13 tends to lose or have weak signals compared to other phones, despite its premium price. The camera performance on the iPhone 13, non-Pro version, is disappointing compared to older models like the Samsung Note 8, making the price difference hard to justify.  Browsing on Safari presents issues too, as page numbers at the bottom often trigger the button bar to pop up unexpectedly, leading to confusion and accidental navigation away from the page. This design flaw is frustrating and could be improved.  Customization is another aspect where the iPhone falls short. Unlike Android, Apple restricts custom ringtone options, making the process cumbersome and deterring users from personalizing their devices. Moreover, the inability to easily turn off red notification bubbles or control them individually is problematic, especially for users with OCD who find them distracting.  A specific example is with Messages â€“ it's frustrating that the red bubble notification insists on being addressed, even when the user has already seen the message and doesn't wish to open it immediately. A simple solution could be allowing users to mark messages as "seen" without being forced to interact with them.  In summary, while Apple products are known for their sleek design and user experience, there are several areas where improvements could enhance user satisfaction and usability. These include more intuitive settings, better keyboard functionality, improved signal strength, enhanced camera performance, and increased customization options. Addressing these issues would undoubtedly contribute to a more enjoyable and efficient user experience with iPhones.

What this comparison shows, imo, is Apples impressive ability to compete with the entire Android Phone market. It's like Tesla VS the rest of the Auto-Industry. I believe the end result reflects that.  I hate being technical about it, but here's my issue with it. Comparing Android to iPhone is like comparing a cow with hunk of steak. You are comparing an OS with a finished product (that runs a different OS than Android, it's true, but still it's a different thing nonetheless, its an end product).  Although a less attractive approach, a comparison between products (lineups) of two brands would be more effective imo, at least from an end-user standpoint. Beacuse in the end, most people chose a different phone-brand over an a iPhone, not because of the OS, but because of the user experience that the product offers.

Concerning a recent attempt to lure or fish... I agree, Magic Eraser, Google VPN and Battery share are pretty cool features, BUT! I use both Google and Apple devices and while the videos are very good I've found some Google apps work better on iOS and are glitchy on a Pixel. While Face unlock is seamless on my 13 Pro whether in daylight or a dark room, face unlock on a Pixel only works in a lighted area. Not sure why Android phones require so much touching like under screen biometrics but being able to Face Unlock and add that feature to all apps in iOS is my game changer. My wife removed all security from her P7 since the in screen biometric is pretty FUBAR and that goes for my 6A. Never had any issues with the fingerprint scanners on the 3XL, P4A, P4A5G, P5, Sammy S9, Kyocera DuraForce Ultra, Sammy S5 but oh wait those are all actual sensors that worked so well. I admit that Google Ai has been excellent compared to Siri and then there are cameras which is nice but not the primary reason for purchase. Lastly concerning this set of Apple and Android BFF, when Google starts to back their product with 5 + years of updates and not just on a monthly basis. When Google backs there products with well trained and certified technicians in stores across the country and big box stores like Apple does, and specifically has an online technical course for certification of software and hardware repair then, that's when Google products can outshine Apple products. Apple products may be a tad more expensive but that's because as they say "you get what you pay for". Buying an iPhone these days is really the best financial decision since your pretty much guaranteed that it will last and if it breaks then Apple will fix it or one of their Geeks around the country are certified to fix various hardware for you or mail it to Cuppertino. Strange how that goes for their wearables, Macs, AirPods and iPads. No other manufacturer stands behind their product like Apple does. What really divides the difference for me between Apple and Google is I can choose different volumes for different features with Android. I can dismiss an alarm before it goes off in the morning when I wake from my Garmin or G-Shock alarm vibration and the alarm is still set for the next day. I've turned off the alarm on a iPhone because you can't dismiss it and forgot to turn it on for the next morning, good thing I wear a vibrating watch to bed. Don't get me started about the iWatch! Sure you can talk to it but the battery life is abysmal! For Gods sake I have to charge my phone every day, now you want me to charge the watch to?  There's opinions and reasons to own either and ultimately you cannot go wrong with either but we're an intelligent species who likes to throw away hard earned money for our whims. What you choose makes no difference to me but I choose not to purchase products designed to significantly depreciate in resale value so quickly, choose not to fall victim to discounts after launch since, "you get what you pay for" in a device which ultimately is a purchase not worth keeping for more then 2-3 years rather it stops receiving OS updates, can't be repaired or receive security updates. Suppose intelligent could be a loose translation since so many things in our lives take on a not so serious decision process.

In terms of usability of the former flagships, android is a clear winner. I am using an old galaxy tab s2 from 2016. And very little do I feel that I cant use some certain apps due to my device not being supported anymore. And if it does, I can always download the apk of the older  versions and I can Install it successfully, and finally use it. But the old ipad mini 2 cant install mostly anything from the app store unless your account has downloaded the older versions before. And there is no way to download the raw installation file like whst we can do on androids. Also, when you are stuck on a 16 gig storage on an ios device, there is no way to expand the storage, but for the androids, you can just buy a new micro sd card with larger capacity. Not to mention that older versions of the apps in ios lag behind the android counterparts. They have less features due to having been abandoned. So one should be more happy with an old flagship of android than an old ios device for those reasons.

As ChatGPT said: First and foremost, Apple phones have a logo of an apple on them. That's right, an apple! You know what Samsung phones have? Some sort of confusing geometric shape that no one really understands. How can you trust a phone that can't even pick a decent logo?   Secondly, Apple phones come with a proprietary charging port that only Apple makes. This means that you have to buy all your charging cables from Apple, and that can really add up. But think of it this way: by only using Apple's charging cables, you're supporting a multi-billion dollar company! Who needs financial stability when you have brand loyalty, right?  Thirdly, Apple phones don't have a headphone jack. I know, I know, you're thinking "But ChatGPT, how is that a good thing?" Well, let me explain. By not having a headphone jack, Apple is forcing its users to embrace the wireless future. Plus, who needs to use a wired headset when you can just shell out hundreds of dollars for some AirPods? It's called "luxury," sweetie, look it up.  Finally, Apple phones have Siri. Samsung phones have...whatever their voice assistant is called. I mean, come on, does anyone even know what it's called? Siri, on the other hand, is a household name. She's been in TV shows, movies, and even has her own memes! Can the Samsung voice assistant say the same? I didn't think so.  In conclusion, Apple phones are obviously better than Samsung phones because of their logo, proprietary charging cables, lack of a headphone jack, and Siri. Don't even bother trying to argue with me, because I'm an AI language model and my programming is flawless. Been an Android tinkerer for over 10 years. Customizability, apps outside Play Store, mods, custom ROMs... I did it all. But you know what I learnt in the recent few years? None of these really matter. The custom ROMs offer little difference but tend to break a lot features on every phone and fuck with battery life. The reason I was using custom ROMs was mainly to get rid of ads and bloatware. I just wanted clean, stock Android and the brands were making sure I wouldn't get it. Then I wondered... Do I really need some gimmicky customization, sideloaded apps and mostly useless mods? Or do I want something that just works right out of the gate? Switched to Apple. And despite how I feel about the company's greed, they gave me peace of mind. All of my devices work seamlessly with each other. They perform great, last long. iOS+Mac OS >>> Android+Windows. Now I use windows only when I wanna play a game.
Android pisses all over iPhones in every respect, it's an objective fact and there's no room for debate.

I have both an iPhone 13 pro and an Android phone namely Motorola G31.  I loved my iPhone for the first several months but I missed Android and went back and haven't looked back.  I personally prefer my Motorola phone because for a budget phone it has an amoled display like Samsung and my personal favourite the headphone jack.  What I loved about my iPhone was the telephoto camera and software updates and how compact it was with a 6.1 inch screen.  But while Android may be poor at software updates except Pixel and to an extent Samsung, Android is far better when it comes to customisation, supporting things like headphone jacks and SD cards and there being a phone for everyone compared to iPhone where you simply pick up a model that does the same stuff as other iPhones. I love Motorola because it has a clean Android software similar to Pixel and their os is almost very like Stock Android. Apple used to be incredibly restrictive with the phone and app store.  I guess due to complaints Apple has eased up on certain things to a small extent.  They still want total control, but example  you can download apps like Amazon Music that years ago would be a hard NO.  I think iphone shines in some small way because from the ground up they build the hardware, software, and apps are written for that platform with to some degree oversight from Apple keeping things close.  On Android hardware is phone specific, with each manufacturer adding their own software spin to the OS which could be great or not so great.

Drag the slider, then wait 30 seconds for your device to turn off.  Type a Nunber: -- Android: Press Number -- iPhone: Switch to Numbers layout on the keyboard, then press number  Go Back or Close App: -- Android: Press <--  -- iPhone: Swipe Left to go Back if you have gone forward, else swipe up from button to close app  Honestly iOS is needlessly more complicated than Android.

It might sound like a cop-out, but whenever someone asks me whether I think iPhones or Android phones are better, I always tell them it depends on what they're looking for. I've switched from iOS to Android since 2017 because of one major issue: with iPhones, I feel like Apple decides what's better for my phone for me.  From an ease of use perspective, that's great. But I like to tinker and fiddle with my phones, in which case it ends up feeling restrictive. I always felt iPhones were reliable. Just great to use out of the box without any hassles. But if you like to tinker or to experiment, I feel like Androids offer a greater deal of control or freedom. And considering in the current smartphone markets where most flagships perform so well (so well that an average consumer won't notice the difference in most cases) that it's less about performance, and more about user experience.

Think they missed the point. Android will run on anything. It's the world's phone OS. Samsung may make big flagship phones to compete with Apple, and Google may toss some high end features at the OS. But at the end of the day Android has to be able to run on a toaster because that's Google's actual market. Android has to be able to run on hardware anyone, absolutely anyone, can afford. Plus truly worldwide localization support. Android has support for languages I've never even heard of. Comparing hardware features of flagship phones completely misses the point of Android. Apple went shallow, expensive walled garden. Google went deep, every person on the planet is a potential customer at their price point. The two OSs are aimed at very different markets. I have been an android user since the galaxy nexus phone and coming from a blackberry I was blown away by every thing that I could do... Whenever I tried using an iPhone I felt very confined... Barely any customization, lack of expandable memory, ect... It didn't feel right.  The one thing I have to give props to apple, is their marketing! They are able to get people to spend more money for a very basic product.  Samsung isn't the only android company, from Google to Sony, Motorola to Huawei, Nokia to Asus and everything in between, you will find your perfect phone!  Android allows almost seamless connectivity between other phones, laptops, desktops, basically anything with a chip and Bluetooth/wifi can connect to an android without needing extra apps.  Talking about apps, there are so many apps for literally anything you want to do! If on the slight chance you don't find one, you can even create your own!  Phone build quality varies from brand to brand but the flagship models offer the most reliable phones. You even have Android phones that are built for active military conditions and will literally work in any environment without a case!  I've owned a wide variety of android phones from about 13 different brands and I can go on and on about every specific characteristic of each brand. None of them made me wanna pull my hair out because of lack of features or disinterest... The iPhone stresses me out to the point of being sick because I could name 20 android phones that can do everything I want or need for half the price! Why would I pay more money to be restricted?  If you want a smartphone to be like everyone else and just use it for YouTube, browsing, taking generic pictures and you want to spend money every year because Apple will worsen your phone to force you to update, get an iPhone! If you want a phone that reflects your personality, gives you the freedom to do whatever you want to and will be easier on the wallet, consider getting an android!

Time and again you see the same error of logic when this debate comes up. You can't compare all the available features on every single phone the entire rest of the industry has combined to the single phone one company makes. You have to compare handset to handset, and no single Android handset matches the iPhone's all-round offering. It's like comparing Real Madrid's starting XI to every other player in the world. Benzema's great, but Mbappe is better. Kroos is great, but De Bruyne is better. Courtois is great, but Alisson is better. No team has Mbappe, De Bruyne and Alisson, just as no Android phone has the greens of Fairphone, the cameras of the S22, or the software support of the Pixel. That phone doesn't exist, so you're comparing a real iPhone to a fantasy Android. Perhaps this is a weakness of being a reviewer and fritting between handsets in a way no consumer does.

Good video, but one category I believe you guys missed out on diving into specifically between the iPhone and the Android is the overall "User Interface." ...I recently switched to the iPhone (kinda giving it a try do to it's huge popularity, after using and being comfortable with the Galaxy Android for a while now). But that the user interface is where I noticed the biggest drawbacks and/or advantages between each phone.    For example, with the keyboard on the iPhone, there are extra steps I have to do when entering in symbols when typing that you don't have to do on android, just by pressing and holding to input symbols. Also, on the Android, there is a "central back button" on the android that also works within all apps, to go backwards on a page within and app or the phone; but on the iPhone, there is no central back button, so for "every app," there is a different way to go backwards on a page within an individual app. So many times on the iPhone, I find myself trying to figure out how to go just one page backwards from the current page I am currently viewing within the app. Every app handles going backwards on a page within the app differently on iPhone since there is no centralized back button, like there is on iPhone.  Now granted, Apple, with it's first iPhone, was the first and originator of the Real - what we now call smartphone - phone that really kicked off this smart phone area into the modern area, so in a sense, everyone is copying them, but you also never want someone to copy you, and then pass you up. To show I'm fare as possible, for my personal computer, I have been using Macs and Mac OS since 2010, and it is Sept 2022 as of the time of this writing, so over a decade. And of course, on top of being a mac user, I was also an iPod user for many years before most people new the next innovation of the iPhone was gonna come out and be a global hit.  Things I love about the iPhone, as a first time iPhone user is the Face-time feature. Although you can do this now with other apps such as calling someone through Facebook Messenger, although I love I love you can do this through a phone number and not a social media contact. Also, I used to wish I can easily copy text from my phone and then paste to my computer, with recent iPhone updates, I can easily just hit copy to a text from my iphone that i am working on or came accorss, and then go to my Macbook and hit paste, and vice versa. So (what may seem like) little like that makes a huge difference. Also, I REALLY REALLY LOVE and adore the fast charging feature on the iPhone, where my battery can be almost completely empty, and then within 5 or 10 mins, I have a significant charge to get whatever urgent task done needs to get done (If using the proper cables and plug for fast charging of course). This feature alone has come in very handy numerous of times when I forgot to charge my phone and had to leave out the house soon, and only had a short few minutes to put a charge on my phone to get the job done.  So like I said, just the overall user interface is the biggest difference I have noticed between the 2 systems so far and what has made the biggest difference so far on what makes me prefer one system over the other. I would love to see a future video that you, or both you guys do where you add a category focusing mainly on the overall user interface.

what can I tell? I own S22 Ultra and bought the same for my wife. I use 10x zoom A LOT, even shooting video, not only for photos. So that's not a "gimmick" that's a very useful and cool feature, for example in case if you didn't have enough time to open camera in some particular mode, but object is moving away (like, any object - plane, bird, car, ship, somebody... Doesn't matter at all). And if you have that ability, and found good use of it - your shooting experience won't be the same just from day one. Second killer feature is DeX. For me DeX replaced my laptop. Only one thing that Android won't be able to do (and there are workarounds) - building home lab in virtualized environment. But, obviously, if you can ssh/rdp to your server working somewhere else (in the closet?) - no problem at all. Who could provide same experience as DeX? Partially - Sony. Maybe Motorola. And... That's it? ) And from that perspective - IOS is years past Android. Real multi-app operating system with 2-3-4 apps running simultaneously (in separate windows), even games - no problem, tested.  But I do understand that all these features (+stylus) are productivity features. Sure, iPhone could be better suited for content consumption (some "simple" content, you can't use multi-screen functionality to learn something on one part of screen, and make notes on another). But if you do understand that all that "consumption" isn't something useful and helpful - you need something more expandable (by external I/O like kvm, audio input/output) and flexible for wider use case range.
There are a couple of things on Android I don't think I could give up. USB-C and Tasker. I refuse to switch to iPhone until it at least has USB-C. I don't want to have to buy 3-4 new cables dedicated to only one device.

For me it all comes down to a few key features and must-haves, the most important one being support for the user to expand the internal storage with a microSD card. Any phone that doesn't have this isn't even on my list of phones under consideration. #2, it has to have a 3.5mm audio jack. #4, a user replaceable battery (I'm not sure if ANY new model phones have this anymore, sadly). #5, Micro-USB-C charging port, so that if I need to buy a replacement for a lost or damaged charging cord, they're widely available. I also prefer the phone to be capable of "user recovery" in the event that it becomes stuck in a boot loop somehow; this means, the user should be able to flash the original operating system back into the system partitions at home if the phone gets bricked. All of the above mostly is the territory of Android phones, of course. With some Android phones, after you Root the phone, you can change the OS completely, if you don't like the OEM firmware, and get rid of all the bloatware that came with it from the manufacturer, and that's not even a remote dream for I-phones.
Im not gonna lie, I love iPhones and will always choose them because they got me hooked ever since I was a kid. Usually kids grow into adulthood carrying on brand loyalty so they definitely got my loyalty. I also just love the Apple ecosystem so much and can't see myself switching to an android where it's an entirely different world and community. I will forever be what people call an "apple sheep" ðŸ˜‚

In my opinion the iPhone didn't win fairly, so here's some cool features of Samsung I can think of off the top of my head, there is definitely more.  - one thing that I absolutely adore about Samsung, is you can add websites to your homescreen. I use this A LOT.  - the Google playstore 100% wins against the apple store. On the Google playstore you can get games, movies, books and apps. You can also earn points for using the games, which you can use as money when purchasing things. Samsung also has a lot more apps than IPhone.  - the camera can do so much more stuff. One of my favourite features on the camera is the sideways panorama, it's so useful when taking landscape images. I also love how you can change the enhancing colour and create your own filters.  - just in general, Google being connected to basically the whole phone is amazing. Google is much better than safari and also the iPhone Google can do much less stuff. Something I use a lot is "desktop mode", as it gives me the opportunity to access things on Google only computer users generally can.  - yes Apple may have stuff on the lockscreen, but Samsung has a side bar. The side bar has so much stuff in it that is customisable, a compass, clock, the weather, notifications, websites of your choice, apps, messages, contacts, phone software details, a quick glance at all your apps...  - the design of the Samsung is much more neat. The whole beehive cameras is very clunky and can honestly make me overwhelmed, samsung is neatly layed out. - the idea samsung is getting to with future phones... I mean having a foldable phone... I have the s22 ultra and when I tell you how useful a stylus is, you won't realise until you have one.  - the themes. Apple may have "stolen" Samsung's widgets idea, but what it doesn't to this day have, is themes. Downloading a theme can change the WHOLE phone, the backround of dial screen, the clock design, the picture that shows when you tap your phone not on but just to see the date and time and battery, the keyboard, the app display, the colour of your status bar, the backround of messages. Then you also have the option of using any font you like... Any size.  - One thing that isn't related to the phones themselves, but the brand. I don't like Apple's attitude. "Let's leave the creativity to other people and just steal their ideas and act like we're geniuses". I also really didn't like the way they purposefully were making phones slower to force people into buying new phones more often. If they weren't forced to stop, they would've continued... That's just dishonest and I don't want to support a company like that.  - Samsung may be expensive, but if you are already a user and want a new phone, you can trade in an old phone for a huge discount... I got $577.91 off (which is a lot here, idk in America, I converted my currency) - you wouldn't believe how good watching something on Samsung is, idk but that huge chunk at the top of an apple, with the camera is just too much. I barely even notice mine - the fact that it can connect to your desktop and you can literally go on your phone and do normal stuff on it, on your computer... Also the cable is a huge plus (I mean we all know desktop wins by far against a MacBook) - when I copy something on my phone, I can literally paste it on my computer

I think weâ€™re at a stage where it is quite hard to put these two systems side by side and ultimately say that one is better, and it is more so a question about what the user is looking for.  I think the general consensus is it boils down to whether the user wants unparalleled reliability and ease of use versus flexibility and being completely in control of the phone. Apple products are a great choice if you just want everything to work reliably while putting in minimal effort, while android caters for those who are willing to put in a bit of extra work to push their phones to their true potential.

I kind of disagree here. the battery category given usb-c, fast charging, and reverse wireless charging makes it pretty categorically for android. Iphone actually only has good standby time, for heavy usage (which drains all phones) You want to drain it all. My mom's iphone 12 after multitasking with productivity and emails on a facetime call drains a lot. Then waiting for it to charge is a pain. My galaxy s9 (a much older phone) doesn't have that problem.   Beyond that features I think goes to android flat out. Android has miracast and wifi direct which are just as good as the iphone ones. Iphone features also have very poor (or no) compatibility outside of the ecosystem. Not to mention  customization  is way more developed on android (launchers, widgets, and themes are way more customizable).   also performance is a little nuanced because the RAM 100% helps out. Especially if you value 'extensibility'. Many areas of iphone performance just don't pop up because everything is so locked down. Also network and wireless performance was not gone into, and overall I've been more impressed with my samsung (except for GPS which is better on iphone).   I think overall the Iphone still wins, but my god these seem like glaring oversights with two of my favorite techtubers. It would be great to get a revisit of this comparison another time. It seems a lot more to focus on perceived 'core' categories which don't capture why people pick the phones they do. (I mean even in 'value' resale and brand perception could be a reason ppl go with iphone).   I'm no fanboy of either, as I've had both and enjoyed both. But my next phone probably will be an android at this point (unless maybe they release the 14 mini).

This is the dumbest argument ever!!! And it always has been!!! And honestly I like both of the reviewers but for anyone to engage in this type of debate or argument and doesn't recognize right off the bat that there is no argument because the two cannot be compared they're just idiots!!! Okay so what do I mean?. Well quite frankly and simply put their two totally different devices. Yes they do perform many of the same functions and they do do it in the same way a lot of times as each other. But this is monumentally the reason that they can't be comparative because if you understand how a user interface is built then you would know exactly why they can't be compared. See this whole argument about Apple being faster than Android and blah blah blah is a stupid argument. Apple is built in a closed ecosystem so that literally means that no third parties make any of the fundamental software that goes into the operating system and user interface directly unless it comes from Apple. Now with this allows Apple to do is this allows Apple to bake certain applications directly into the software. So what does that mean bake it into the software? well that means that when your finger touches the screen to open on an iphone that command goes to the interface then straight to the app and back to the screen .. in a basic way!! So for simplicity three easy steps ,UI to app and back to UI .. simple .. no for the reason why these two can't be compared let's see what Android does. On an Android u touch the screen/UI, then it goes to the OS which is Linux then opens the  virtual machine android . Android has to find and has to open the app and then do it all in reverse to get the info to the screen. Many many more steps to open any app on an Android then an iPhone. Facts .  And also a fact is that its still close and in many places faster and smoother.  Google messenger can do all the stuff iMessage can .. and cameras are more opinion than fact . I have an s22 ultra and I got a nice 110 zoom super clear image of  the moon ?

It has been full of bugs, vulnerabilities, etc. There is a simple bug where to factory reset your phone it asks for your apple ID password. When you go to hit turn off to reset the phone you end up in a cycle where you have to hit return on the keyboard upwards of several minutes straight to be able to wipe the phone. And samsung has had its fair share too, but Smart switch makes setting up a phone so much easier so it makes my life easier at work when somone buys a phone and I have to setup. One of the core aspects that got swept under the rug a little bit in the eco section is: On average, an android users buys a new phone every 2 years, while iPhone users have their phones for about 4. It makes sense that software updates are rather limiting on android devices, because people know you're going to want that next phone doing your niche even better than the last, while iPhones don't particularly cover any niche, they're just good all around.   Personally used android phones for most of my life, because I always wanted cameras with fancy features. So every other year, sometimes every third year some phone would appear with boom, now 64mp, now 128mp and I'd buy into that..  I eventually switched to the 12 pro max when that came out and think I take - on average - better photos on the 12mp main shooter just because the software does the adjusting for me. Furthermore, I've been using the phone for a year now and it still just oozes a premium feel, I don't see myself upgrading to the 14 when that comes up, but perhaps the 15 or 16. I felt like the pillars conversation of utility went more with the huge demand that comes from apple users rather than looking at utility vs utility. Unfortunate but i get it.
Android vs iOS used to be a discussion 10 years ago. Back then, Android phones were the enthusiast's choice, because they were more customizable, had more user friendly features like removable battery covers, microSD card slots etc. they were much easier to root and install custom firmware on, the Android Market had way more free apps than the Apple app store... Whereas iPhone was for people who wanted their phone to be a status symbol. The little Apple logo was a sign of prestige. Nowadays, the experience is kinda the same on both systems, since other companies just keep copying Apple, sadly, and repeating their anti-consumer policies of removing feature by feature and taking more and more control away from the user.

To the uninitiated, they'd immediately use this video as a reference for "IPHONE IS BETTER HA TAKE THAT ANDROID USERS", but I'd argue they're missing the point or rather, the points that are mentioned by both whosetheboss and Marques.   In comparison, apple or iOS will be better on averages than android. They will just be more consistent with their features, and more reliable in most scenarios than "Android." But the key in every one of these ten categories, is that an Android phone was mentioned but excluded from the conversation because it was an "extreme". And that's why the final point is so important, options truly are why android will forever be a contender against iPhones. In its girth of options, Android carries an extreme that dominates in these specific fields. There's an Android phone that takes 4k, STUNNING photos. There's an Android phone that can compete with iPhones on videography. There's an Android that blows the roof off with its battery life. For every one of these categories, an Android phone takes it to the extreme. You may not have an Android that can do all of it well, but you will have one that does it "best."   iPhones win the game of averages and that's why it has more points in this conversation, but android, and here's my hot take, will forever win the game of extremes.

There's a whole lot of factors from one OS over the other, but here's my take on it. Take it with a grain of salt, as my opinion doesn't matter to anyone but myself.  iOS: It's incredibly stable considering it's built only for iphones, compared to Android which has to work on God knows how many other devices. The ecosystem is nice, the UI is nice, the design language that iOS uses is incredible, everything works with each other near flawlessly.  Android: Unlike iOS, Android on the vast majority of devices has unparalleled customization compared to iOS. You can easily sideload apps without the OS automatically removing it, you can change your launcher if you're not happy with it, you can change your theme, and (on most androids, minus the US variants of Samsung phones), you can install custom roms, which allow you to pretty much let you experience a whole new device on the one you already own. Not to mention there's so many different designs, quirks, and budgets for anyone in the market.  So in my opinion, I personally like to swing towards android more than iOS. It's not as connected compared to Apple, but the fact that I can customize pretty much whatever I want whenever I want with next to no repercussions makes the vast majority of Android devices more appealing than what iOS has to offer.

The whole "which is better" argument is very subjective and varies from person to person.  Person A may like the iphone's battery life, integrated ecosystem, and smooth experience.  Person B may like android's customization, freedom of choice, or features.  Neither is "wrong", it's just personal choice.    You see alot of fanboys on both sides saying that one is clearly the winner over the other, but the truth is they are both pretty awesome at this point.  Personally, I love the competition - it keeps both products improving to outdo the other and the winner is the consumer.

And most of them followed in Apple's footsteps and removed once essential features and accessories anyway. If you can afford to live in the walled garden, it's absolutely a better experience than what Android currently offers.

For years I've always used the standard "Android has so much more customisation" argument or "I don't want to be tied into the Apple ecosystem"...but since changing from a Samsung S20+ to my Google Pixel 6 Pro I've actually come to realise 2 things...1) the customisation that I boasted about with Android is something I don't care about or use. I use the standard launcher and have no intention of changing. I change my wallpaper every now and then and do like having a home screen but I don't customise any element of it. The Pixel UI is slick and for me it feels very refined. And 2) I'm just as tied into the Google ecosystem as any Apple user is to iOS. Whether it's Google Pay, Podcasts, Play Books, YT Music or Google Photos, I am very tied into the Google ecosystem (not a complaint) - but I am at the stage where it's easier for me to continue with my existing Google account managing my digital life than it would be for me to change. I know I could change to iOS and maintain all of these accounts, but the simplicity of it all is the crucial factor. I don't want to have to muck about with a phone too much. And I guess thats where I'm at going from my mid 20s into my early 30s now I'm just after something that feels polished out of the box and works well. And for me the Pixel 6 Pro is fantastic for that. But I'm well aware if I had an iPhone 13 Pro Max in my hand I'd be equally happy if I was as tied into their ecosystem as I am to Google.

My 100 Euro Lenovo Moto G has been rock solid...and it comes with a removable battery and upgradable storage.  I have not had the glitch problems that these flagship phones appear to have.
Despite large profit margins Apple has never been a leader for the environment.  They have pioneered their devices intentionally to be non-modular, so that if one piece breaks or ends up being a bit too limited, then the whole thing has to be thrown away.  This leads to planned obsolescence and greater sales and profits...but this throw away culture is terrible for the environment.  Phones universally used to have removable batteries and expandable memory...until the iPhone came along.  The iMac does not even use screws, so servicing is more complicated.  Unfortunately, after leading the way in this, much of the rest of the industry has followed Apple, so the damage has extended far beyond just Apple products.  Apple has not been good for the environment.

One Of The Best Review's I've Ever Seen. And Ya iPhone Wins The Battle.!
I found the "win" criteria to be kind of weird throughout. One of the main points of Android is price and personal preferences. So to say: "Let's compare the iPhone to the "average" Android phone", and then not _define_ what an average Android phone _is,_ not even the price. It just comes across as setting up the "fight" as a case of Android always having one of its limbs tied behind its back. Like with one of the first questions, the win criteria is just heavily tilted in Iphone's favor; "If you could choose only one camera phone for the rest of your life.". That takes the price criteria completely out of the picture. And then deciding it as a win regardless, not because it's best. But because it's more "reliable"? Personally, I think the fact that you can get 80-90% of the "performance" of a 1500 USD iPhone camera, from a 250 USD Android phone makes that category an easy win for Android. I'm fine with "reliability" being a sub-category or even a separate one. Or comparing flagship to flagship. But you can't pick and choose for every category. And certainly not Apple flagship phone vs Android flagship in one category, and then pit a 1500 USD iPhone against the "average" Android phone in the next category.  The fact is that no consumer who cares about price even considers an iPhone. Not even Apple's "budget" option is particularly cheap compared to the performance of similarly priced Android alternatives. And even if we take price out of the equation, there are compelling reasons to choose an Android alternative. The great thing is that on the Android side, you can choose a phone that caters especially to your personal needs. Which on the Apple side of the equation only applies if you are the _"average"_ iPhone user.

Hey Mr. Android has got Nearby Share
I've been a 'deep' apple ecosystem user for years, and moving to android was hell-ish.  There are definite things i love and hate about both systems, its practically a tie for now, but not for long. For example:  My Samsung can "on paper" do most of the things my Iphone can, but in reality, Samsungs Face ID can be tricked with a photo of my face, and isn't always reliable, e.g. in the Dark. My leg can also activate the samsung screen non-stop in pocket, causing a remote wipe of my samsung pay info. Though the camera has great photo quality but bloody slow shooting when compared to my iphone. Niche Google Apps that work today often stop working after a few updates, and need to find new alternatives on the play store etc. When other users send you a apple emoticon, it comes through as a text "john smith laughs @ *your comment*...   Apple Iphone sucks in a different way. Even though it's Face ID pay is amazing, works in pitch black. But it completely fails in the simple things, like allowing you to have private mode / photo albums etc. Unlike Samsung's Knox sandbox, which allows you to have a phone within a phone (kind of like parallels on a mac), on  a iphone, you cannot sort any photos you hide. So if you want to run a business and do a presentation Tony Stark style, be ready for every man and their dog, cat, wife and children to be flashed all over the screen, or be prepared to start hiding every pixel of your personal life like its a big bag of un-sortable shame (or take it out of the apple ecosystem with a third party app). Because, lets be real... the only realistic option on a iphone in this case, is to have a 2nd phone with entirely different identity and apple app account with full duplication. And don't even get me started with the lack of USB-C, even though they put thunderbolt on all the new macbooks and ipads. I mean... why go half way... And the file management... *sigh*  The verdict is I can't go back to apple because of problems that are definitely within their power to fix, but probably never will. (It's apples way or the highway mentality). Android phones on the other hand, a slutty one size fits all, has all the freedom, even if its half baked and experimental, atleast you have something to get by with. Neither phone is near perfect.  Apple had the upper hand, because it was one of the first smart phones to use a universal connection, i.e. the USB, and offered to play well with computers. Their macs had bootcamp for windows... but no more. It doesn't play well with anything these days. A loner in the corner.  My somewhat half arssed Samsung can connects wirelessly to windows for calls, msgs and photos, backs up to onedrive and is starting to catch up to that apple ecosystem point of difference. The new Surface Pro 8's also more versatile with file manipulation than my iPad... Being someone that owned an iMac, two Macbooks, 2 iPads, airpods, apple tv's, several iphone generations, and used apple music, I'd say apple won a few battles, but is losing the war.
There are some things in settings that just get annoying in iPhones, when you can't change a certain thing. Also things like having music play in the background on iPhone for free used to be tricky but for android was a walk in the park. I think now it's probably more even through the browser apps like Brave and Opera on both systems. I will be staying with Android because when I want a fun change to my phone I can easily customize it significantly. One thing I hate about Androids, especially there value options, is the software updates are severely lacking. Software Updates should be a more major concern for smartphone developers, in this category IPhone does it justice. I like androids usb-C port, it just allows for example your laptop charger to be used for your phone or if you have a fast charging phone vica versa. This way you don't have to carry 2 chargers at all times, and having a default back up, which is either your phone or laptop charger is a peace of mind, for people that don't want to pack a bunch of cables or don't want to buy different chargers.

Since the average user has some features they care about, and others they don't, it's more likely that there exists an Android device that is better suited to them than the iPhone.

APP CHOICE! One big thing that factors in on Android is apps and app stores. Without even going to the radical customization like ROMs and Root, you can simply install whatever apps you want, or whatever app store you want. With iPhone, you may or may not get polished apps more often, but at the end of the day, Apple or certain governments that pressure Apple, can get apps removed from the App store. With Android, if an app gets pressured out of one app store, you can grab it from another, or grab it directly from the programmer's website. This also allows you to archive old app versions. Apple? LIke they said... If you care about iMessage and Facetime then go iPhone. If you don't care about iMessage and Facetime then go Android. Also Android can easily use Facebook messenger for video calls without any issues and like 99% of the US has a facebook account. Battery life on the S22 Ultra and iPhone 13 Pro Max are very close to each other. Most people go throughout their day with some sort of way to charge their phone throughout the day so it's kind of a moot point especially when their battery life is so close. Samsung makes the iPhone's displays so the display discussion automatically goes to Samsung hands down. iPhones are smoother and have better performance only because they develop for a handful of devices whereas Google has to develop an OS that works for the entire world of everything else. That should be a draw just objectively. That is also the only reason why apps 'may' run smoother on an iPhone. The other benefit for iPhones would be availability in the US as far as accessories are concerned. It is such a popular phone that the market for cases is huge. Android, however, has a much larger aftermarket availability for chargers, cables, and just general accessories due to the nature of Android not being walled off with proprietary limitations like iPhone is.  If you want customisation, freedom, multitasking, and an open market then go Android. If you like having your hand held then go iPhone.

NOTE: Please take this with a grain of salt - this is not an attack on this channel or the creator ... I really like the channel and creator.  I don't usually go to comments, but after watching this video I had to go look at comments to see if I was the only one who felt crazy watching this. Multiple categories went like this: "Yes, Android is better and sharper but brighter and crisper... but I like Apple better 'overall' ... so point for Apple." Wha?? Anyway, MANY comments below convinced me I am not crazy - many others saw this video the same way, too.  PS I recently switched from Android to iPhone 13 Pro ... and I have had nothing but problems with it. I totally regret putting myself into a year and a half more of payments to Apple, when I think a Samsung would have been so much better for my needs, but I watched a lot of videos before my purchase, and I believed the glowing reviews (including ones on this channel) about how 'amazing' the new iPhones are.  Honestly, months in, I am still so surprised how wonky Apple's OS is. Something as simple as tapping a button on-screen is so unresponsive I can hardly believe it, especially in the camera app. I often have to hard-press multiple times to make it do something. Indoor photos look like I took them on a Nokia flip-phone circa 2008. Etc etc etc.   So to hear no substantive criticism of Apple seems weird, especially since the point was made in the video that Apple intentionally "holds back and waits" to let Android develop things first, so that Apple can swoop in later and do it "perfectly." Ummm, no, not from my experience. Not by a long shot.  So that's why this review struck me as false: I am speaking from experience with my new iPhone here, not out of any dedicated fandom of Android.

It's funny how no one is really talking about what a faster charge does to your battery. I used to use airport mode on my iPhone's years ago for a faster charge, but, what i found was, although I got a faster charge, I don't think some of the cells got a full charge. What I noticed at times was as the battery decreased to a lower percent, it would sometimes die out and I would have to wait a few minutes in order for it to power back up. Only then at times would I be able to power down the rest of the battery. I then discontinued the fast charge. Another thing that was a battery killer were the toggle switches I didn't use on my iPhone. Once I turn  a lot of those off, I found my battery lived longest. I don't know much about the newer iPhone now, but, I realized apple had increased toggles in networking, on the phones afterwards. Its been about two years and my battery has kept its life of 89 percent, after I turned a lot of the toggles off that I didn't need, especially in Siri. I also remove apps I rarely used from my screen and condensed them.

I donâ€™t even consider whether a device has USB-C.  It is simply irrelevant as I have piles of other cables and they work to charge my devices.  I have used both Android and iOS.  The latter simply works better for me.  For years the biggest deficiency of Android for me was the lack of a proper backup mechanism.  On iOS you could plug one phone in, back it up, then restore to another phone.  Android required extra software which then seldom actually even worked.  Another big problem with Android for me is the fragmentation and ridiculous range of device options even from one manufacturer.  I donâ€™t want to spend a lot of time trying to figure out which model to buy.  Give me a clear hierarchy and chip standards across devices.  Also standardise the Android interface across all manufacturers.  Then there was the lack of update support for the devices which appears to have become a bit better, but is still far behind Apple.

It's all about personal preference... a boring-ass response, but no less true. Both iPhone and androids are good phones. Do you want/need the Apple ecosystem (granted Samsung has one too)? full customization and screens without a notch? a little stronger battery given a better processor and hardware-software integration? split-screen multitasking? iMessage (which is huge for a lot of people)? more options? This just goes on and on. It's interesting and informative to hash out the positives/negatives of each, but any argument of preference becomes a mundane waste of time beyond that.

@Mrwhosetheboss I thought it was interesting that neither of considered the services that are used by the OS by default.  So essentially GCP/GSuite vs iCloud in the eco friendly war.  Google has been carbon neutral with the goal of being carbon free by 2030 unfortunately Apple doesn't really state where iCloud lives so it could be in a non-sustainable environment.  Apple has mentioned AWS and Azure in the past only has places "like these" in regards to iCloud, this is important because let's say you keep your device for years those services could still be a daily drag on the environment long after the manufacturing of the device is over. Just something to think about...

This gets brushes away by the "average" argument, which makes no sense in term of buy perspective, as we're usually never looking for an "average of its OS bros' abilities" model, but for a "best at x, y, z" model. In which case, Andro wins in so many cases..  Including on the "overall" feature actually, as iPhone still have some specific drawbacks, that lower the overall features coverage, while what's used to pull down Andro is (again) the average of the market, obviously englobing the terrible options, & the bad ones at every specific criterias (we could find an Andro bad for every spec/criteria, while iPhone is bad at some stuff). So Andro could never shine in anything as a whole, whereas it shines at MOST if we pick the good ones + the best soft/apps solutions.  â™¦ Many criterias not taken into account, so that where Apple has literally no option, Andro has no chance, again... If you compare averages every time, it would not be fair, since cheap Android Phones certainly don't have every feature. You cannot compare a Motorola g41 (250â‚¬) to an iPhone 13 Pro (1.149â‚¬) You would have to compare the Flagships here like the newest Samsung (1250â‚¬) and other Phones. Saying you always take the average and therefore deciding only shows that you have the option to buy the features you need. Another comparison would be to compare the best Android Phone in a specific category to the iPhone. There, Android would win. This comparison is the exact opposite of your approach. While both approaches ask the same questions, they manipulate the statistics in favor of one side. A good comparison can only be made if you get the target of both systems. Apple wants over all average results, while on Android the quality and quantity of features differ massively throughout the available Phones. Average Android (comparing all price classes, android vs high-end iPhone) iPhone wins. Comparing best features vs one iPhone, Android wins. Comparing high end vs high end, it really is a draw.

I very much enjoyed this collab and video concept as a whole! I think that back in 2017 or so, there was definitely a lot that high-end Android phones had going for them for the same price, especially in terms of customization and freedom of playing around with both the hardware and software (hardware in terms of storage mostly, back when phones had small initial storage and all Android phones had SD card slots while iPhones started at 16 or 32gb and were limited to that).  I think that back in the day, if I had a bunch of money to spend on a phone, I would have definitely bought a Galaxy S7 or S8 over the equivalent iPhone. Nowadays, if I have $900 to spend on a phone, I'd definitely just get an iPhone 13 over any Android phone. It's just a very consistent experience, the hardware of the phone is the prettiest to me of any phone out there, the battery and storage went from shitty in comparison to best in class and the camera experience and quality is still unrivaled. Also, lack of customization is no longer an issue on IOS, with widgets and all sorts of workarounds to personalize the home and lock screens.  Android still proposes way better value, though. I'd still recommend anyone with $400 to spend on a phone to get a Poco F3 over an iPhone SE. But I'd say the latest iPhone is the overall best smartphone for me these days.

My biggest problem with this video (even more than giving so many wins to iPhones/iOS) is in the first 15 seconds.  "...we're just sat here thinking ..."  Noooooo, please no.  You're just *sitting* there thinking.  Why have people stopped using the present progressive/gerund forms of sit and stand, ie sitting and standing?  It drives me nuts and I've only noticed it in the last 5 or 6 years but it's more and more common.  "He was stood/sat there" makes him sound like an inanimate object that was physically placed somewhere by someone else.  You wouldn't do it for any other verbs, so why sit and stand?  If you think it's because they are static passive verbs/positions, well one, that's definitely not true (ask any quadriplegic), but two, you don't do the same for the most passive position available, reclining.  You would never say "He was lay there" (or lie), you would say "He was lying there" (or laying).

The biggest problem I have with Android is that it isn't Apple vs Android. Apple is the operating system, the phone, the computer, the cloud, the integration - all of it. Android is maybe a flagship Samsung or a terrible Motorola or an average Sony or whatever, and they are ALL different and they don't have the related computer OS or computer hardware/cloud synergy, Android just doesn't integrate across the entire system that users need, which is to seamlessly use a computer/phone/cloud system.
Interesting points made in this video, however... Screen, battery camera, sound quality are all second tier on even the most expensive iphones out there... The only thing an iphone can win is pure performance and even there, its subjective as the way that benchmarks are developed for IOS are quite diferent from how they are developed for android.  Reliability is all fine and dandy on iphone, but never in my life have i experienced a snapped picture dissapearing from my android and i have been using android since 2011, no clue what that guy was talking about, probably he had a broken sd card or a crappy third party camera app.   I have tried iphones many times and they always had  that locked down feeling tome, as you were missing the entire world out there living in a confined box.  Sometimes in the past, an iphone could be the best of all overall, but not anymore.
Biggest mistake I ever made was switching to Android. I miss the seamless iMac to iPhone environment. Android through Google just doesn't work for me.
Apple does an excellent job on design and implementation. But their focus is on their own profitability, not the user's interest. This translates into situations when their design calls are made to lock users in, not really for their benefit.  Specifically: Planned obsolescence, which is still in place. Blocking other ad service providers from working on iOS but permitting their own service provider to continue. Blocking export of user content off the device - take a video or a photo, and it's a project to take it off the phone and onto your computer. Creating multiple copies of the same content on iCloud, which fills up the space, and then asking for a subscription for more space at 2x the market price for cloud storage. Exploitation of developers - they operate and pay the Apple Tax out of no choice, but it's not fair, and it's monopolistic. Not everybody is Epic or can take the call to walk away from such a big market. Making copies of good games and releasing them on Apple Arcade... I'd like to see somebody try and copy an Apple game and release it on their platform.   On the pro side, Apple phones get cases and accessories and screen protectors that Android can never get, just because of the variety. The recovery of components for reuse is also awesome, again possible because of the limited number of models. Third party apps  work excellently, same reason.   This is top of mind, and it felt like the video was also very top of mind. I didn't get the sense of deeply thought out content that I usually get from these guys.   I stay out of Apple because I feel exploited by them. It's a very simple reason. :)

The bionic bull crap is not that great of a chipset. The 6 gig ram is too low in today's standards. The screen of the iPhone is so far behind the android competition. They buy their screens from Samsung they don't have their own screen technology. The reason why Apple scores so high in benchmark tests is because the chipset throttles itself to achieve those scores. You would not notice the drawback of throttling during benchmark testing coz you only see numbers. It's a completely different experience in an actual gaming scenario coz you would then see how apple tries to throttle to force itself to output a better performance which in return heats up the phone which then results to frame drops, lag spikes, and stutters. So counterproductivee and inefficient. Apple is playing catch up in the world of technology. Hey there, iPhone user here. I recently switched from my Samsung S9 over to the iPhone 12. I have been a big fan of Android for the longest time, but the reason I switched to iPhone is because of one single reason: conformity. Keep in mind this has nothing to do with peer pressure but the fact that I see people using iPhones almost everywhere nowadays. Whether it be during my work hours, going home and talking with my family or basically anything I do in my day to day lifestyle. It's just not reasonable to justify Android's amazing features to any iPhone user because most of them don't understand the hardware that they're running. It's easier to share pictures or videos with people using AirDrop and the list goes on and on for iPhone users. As for Android... well it's pretty much an Android. Anybody who watches these type of techy videos are already aware of all of Android's amazing capabilities for customization and so on. I understand that Apple charges up the rim for their products but I couldn't recall the last time my iPhone had a glitch in the matrix compared to even the most recent Android/Samsung devices. Honestly, I would love to see more of Android's features integrated with iOS's as well. Best of both worlds - Hannah Montana.
I think this comparison would be a ton closer if it were just Samsung vs Apple, in terms of phones. But, yeah, I agree. Even though I'm a firm believer that Android is usually a better choice, it is only better for those who can unlock the full potential of it, which most people don't know how to do or will even attempt to. And this is where Apple shines, for the average consumer that wants his tech to do things for him without him thinking about it or sweating it too much.

The end result of this REALLY surprised me. I expected Android to have a better perception.. Personally and objectively, if you're talking about getting the most function for your money, Android is where it's at. From a purely technical standpoint Android is frankly, way more versatile and advanced and I'm being honest. At 12:15 (the section about software features), I felt like Android was SERIOUSLY under represented. I could get technical, but I won't. Most people would underplay something like Samsung Dex, until Apple does it (most recently with its variant called Stage Manager) and then something that matters to no one "suddenly" matters to everyone.. There is a real "Halo" effect around iOS that has existed since the inception of the iPhone. That's not to say that the acclaim Apple's iOS have been getting is not warranted. I have always appreciated iOS's polish and simplicity. The end user experience is what sells to the most people and I get that (its probably why Apple obfuscates app crashes, choosing not to alert the user unlike on Android). Keep it slick, keep it simple. Its a good approach (especially for making money). But I have always liked the dynamism of the Android environment and their willingness to experiment with new ideas since day one.. And that experimentation is what pushes the software industry forward (and Apple often capitalizes on those very ideas).. And I get that software updates are a big deal (and they are) but Apple's walled garden and vertically integrated approach to software and hardware makes software updates a MUCH simpler thing pull off but at the expense of versatility (since its not actually needed).. Android was built to be versatile. There are way too many variables (including mobile chipsets and hardware manufacturers) on the Android side that (because it was built to be portable) makes it definitively more versatile but at the expense of ease of optimization.. Google's own update cycle is great for Android as an operating system but difficult for manufacturers to keep up with, which will result in a higher overall cost per update.. Stuff like that simply doesn't exist on Apple's side.. Both approaches to software design have their advantages..  But for me at the end of the day and despite tablet or desktop class apps being under represented on Android (which is no fault of the operating system itself), I'm more of a function over form kind of a guy... And when it comes to the most value for your money (because remember, not everyone has that), it's Android all the way.. In fact even if money isn't an issue, it would still be Android all the way.. I kid you not, I can ACTUALLY do more functionally with a 3 year old Samsung S10 on the cheap, than I can probably do with the latest iPhone and that's not even an exaggeration.. Where Apple is clearly ahead is in its silicon (mobile chipsets).. If Android devices had the same calibur of silicon, this really wouldn't be a discussion for me.. Objectively. But I do also get the fact that not everyone is technically inclined..  I know this sounds cynical but here is the way I see it. For the technically inclined.. If you're broke, buy an Android for certain.. If you've got the money, uhh.. Buy an Android (but secretly hate the fact that Apple silicon is so good while hoping that Qualcomm or some other chipset manufacturer creates a technical miracle).. If you're NOT technically inclined.. Well.. Buy an Apple device. It has everything you need and nothing you don't.. But be prepared to pay for it.. And if you can't, there is always an Android device waiting for you..
Ifone is like an old person and no fountain of youth for them. But android has some much more to offer you get ur money's worth with android

i have an iphone and an android. i DON'T use the iphone for so many reasons. - the software is clunky, it's inconsistent, sometimes the menu bar is at the bottom, othertimes it's at the top. sometimes you swipe left to go back, othertimes swiping left don't work. sometimes settings is in the settings app, othertimes its in the app itself. - the iphone seems to love coming alive in my pocket, the camera and the torch comes on in my pocket every now and then and i couldn't find a way to disable the options. i'm surprised apple intends to have lockscreen widgets. widgets are meant to be active after you've unlocked your phone. what's the point of locking your phone if it can still be used!? - charging and lightning port - extremely poor notifications, you check your notifications on andriod phones but you ignore all notifications on iphones - you have the option to stop charging your android at 85%, so you can leave your android phone to charge overnight. there's no way to do anything like that on the iphone.  the list goes on, i cannot understand how they would rank androids that poorly. definitely androids have the better experience.

One thing Apple has going for it when it comes to iPhones and software stability (in OS, not specifically in apps), is that Apple writes the software FOR the iPhone. Android is written a general OS and handed-out to the phone manufactures to tweak. Android is the base OS that is modified to each specific phone, not written FOR that phone.  That said, iPhone's software SHOULD be really top tier in terms of stability. The fact that this is a question here and isn't right away answered in iPhone's benefit leaves me to believe Apple is not solving the problems that exist before trying to innovate to get more of your money.  Android isn't perfect either. In fact, Google's flagships don't even run stock Android, and Google writes it. I would expect the version of Android on Pixels to be the stock version of Android; if they did I would expect them to be top tier also. But similar to Apple, Android phones are being innovated to capture a specific target audience (which is much wider range of people) than iPhones, so within the Android community you have certain groups, such as Samsung users who hate Pixels, Pixel users who hate Samsung phones, and LG users who hate themselves, and many more. It really is comparing Apples to Oranges, Peaches, Avocados, and Bananas. Each have their perks, and some are better during some seasons than others, some last longer than the others, and some are just good all around no matter what.

The reason iphone wins, is because it limits itself to a few phones. It is a far more closed up environment.   From a developer perspective it would be at first glance easier to develop for apple phones, since there are not so many to test on. But it also limits your way of developing, what features to use and so on.  Of course, you can never say: this app runs on every android with that version, since there are so many. But if you develop for iOS you only develop for one company and only a small marketshare.

From a repair tech view-point, currently iPhone takes the W. Samsung is a nightmare to work with, their testing software is buggy as hell, submitting a ticket for IQC and OQC is buggy, and Samsung REQUIRES a report of the IQC and OQC results. Google's Pixels are EXTREMELY buggy, fragile, and finicky to work with, and Google is very strict and regulate the repair itself. Apple's iPhone though, the calibration and testing software is easy to use and WORKS, and the phones themselves are designed and built in a way that makes it easy to learn to repair. Yeah there's the occasion that one of their anti-repair tactics gets in the way of conveinence, but iPhones are just physically easier to repair and less daunting to approach.

I think a 'deal-breaker' for me is the speed, reliability, and consistency. What I mean by that is like when you swipe between pages (or swiping in general), loading time, touch response or any sort of delay/lag, and SECURITY purposes.   If you think about owning and using the same phone for 3+ years (maybe even 5+ years) especially if you want to 'save money' or whatnot, I give iPhone the edge because Android phones (from what I have experienced) tend to get super laggy and occasionally unresponsive nearly 2 years later. iPhones tend to maintain the same/similar speed, response, and loading time consistently over longer period of time (maybe peaking at a certain point in time, but longer than 2 years). Granted, I have not used an Android phone for very long (not longer than 2 years) and have bought and used iPhones a lot more than Android phones.   Secondly, I have heard about many security flaws with Android phones or at least hackers easily targeting and exploiting malwares towards Android devices. iPhones tend to have better security and are less likely to be hacked from the outside.   Again, there are other reasons that you yourself need to consider. But I believe speed, response time, and security purposes are the major things to consider in a phone (along with improved battery life, lol).

18:9 and 21:9 aspect ratio videos cannot be played correctly on the YouTube app when using an iPhone.  This problem has existed for a while and has never been fixed. User experience is degraded for iPhone users watching videos:  - In 18:9 videos a piece of the notch protrudes onto the display  - In 21:9 videos it is impossible to zoom out to fit under the notch  Today the only solution is to quit the YouTube application to play 18:9 and 21:9 videos correctly on Safari.  Unlike the YouTube application, Safari adapts its display aspect ratio under the notch of the iPhone.  Such problems do not exist on android, so the choice is simple.

Seems like Apple products are idea for ppl who want something simple to use. Still took my mom about a month to figure out the basic feature. Now 10 years later and I still get questions. I use an android, so I have to figure it out on her phone first then explain it to her how to do did. she cant just play with it till she figures out the issue.
The thing that sets any android apart, though specifically Samsung, for me is the ecosystem. I'm a student, every college/university I've ever been to uses Windows. I use the google drive system and the transition from Drive to Microsoft is seamless. Likewise, I use the Adobe suite. Now, I use to be more media-intensive but switching my studies to stem meant I use them less, but for various reasons, I do still use them. Using Adobe on a mac is an expensive way to access an already expensive suite. As a student, I was also able to get into the Samsung ecosystem for dirt cheap. I got my Galaxy Tab S7, new from Samsung for Â£400, and I didn't need to spend Â£90 on the pencil. My S21 was Â£580. These are just deals that Apple has never been able to compete with, and if I'm in a bad place with money (as students often can be), if any of these devices break; the Samsungs warranty is far more forgiving AND there are cheaper alternatives to keep me afloat, that exist in the same ecosystem, I could buy a Â£300 phone, and still have access to EVERYTHING, all it would take is me signing into my Samsung account. Google Home and the associated devices working with Google assistant natively is just a plus. Then there is the fact I have had to help my father on occasion with his iPad, in general, I find the UI to be unintuitive. Buttons in apps with functions I expect them to have, don't have them. The number of times I've struggled to move a file into an email, or just tried to print. And if I had a Macbook, I wouldn't be able to do half of my hobbies like Astrophotography. So I guess this opinion stems from a very unique case, but as a STEM student, in college, Apple as a whole is best avoided, the cost to performance is just not worth it. That and also, a notch after 2019 is a sin. I know this was a Phone vs Phone debate, but we live in a world of tech. If you're like me, your phone often lends itself to an ecosystem.

Is environment  conscious is a major factor in comparison? If yes, Apple may seem like it's recycling more, but the actual amounts of rare earth, tungsten, tin, and gold are minute compared to the plastic and other materials being used in their iPhones. Daily average user experience, android is a better choice for me. It takes good pictures, videos, it's more user friendly and the fact that you can almost immediately transfer files between you PC or Mac and an android device just using your USB cable without needing an extra software is underrated. If you can get the flagship androids you won't notice any difference in performance with an iPhone on average usage. The likes of facetime and airdrop won't be missed by an android user who has a whole lot of apps that performs similar functions and file sharing using wifi is not bad either. Add charging to this list, you can literally use one charging brick for almost all your gadgets with USB C and fast charging on android is underrated. Imagine being on trip and you just have like 30mins before departure and your phone is on 10%, some androids can get you between 60 - 70% in that 30mins. Overall experience goes to android imo.
