Basically you're in an environment thats already fallen into the apple eco system. Air drop, i message, face time, everything. Your location thus becomes i phone biased cuz once they enter it there's barely any chance of shifting to android. Say you are in a country where apple isn't the hype, barely has an ecosystem built up, i guess some points may totally shift. Also it's not like android dosent have these, there's chat features, nearby share, duo and stuff like those, but an average Android user barely uses them. Budget and thus value for money matters too. Storage, customisation, options to choose - everything matters in such locations. In a country where iPhone is the thing, yes i phone goes for a win. In a country where there's an actual competition in the market, no, the points may totally shift a bit.

For eco-friendliness _repairability_ counts too, and Apple is probably _the weakest_ here. And even though their self-repair program exists it is still awfully expensive and hard for those who don't make a living repairing iPhones in the Genius Bar. Meanwhile, some Androids are particularly inexpensive for repairs, but I know it's not as good as before for more phones go for OLED screens on the Android camp, even in ultra budget segment.  Meanwhile for pricing _depreciation value_ counts too, considering Arun mentioning buying a used phone or a refurb phone. Except for Huawei 5G phones and iPhones, other phones depreciate heavily as time goes by. As a result, _iPhones are better for the high-end segment_ and if you're on a budget, Androids, especially many recent models _neither YouTuber covered before,_ give better overall CP value, even though some iPhones are sold as cheap as them now

Overall I agree with the iPhone being the winner. However when thinking about what phone to buy next, I am not sure if I will buy an iPhone cause I am really missing a fingerprint reader. I know this sounds minor but if you think about it the thing you do the most with your phone is unlocking it. Not that face ID is bad. I think it's a great addition to a fingerprint reader e.g. when your fingers are wet or something. But there are many cases where face ID just doesn't work and I always see iPhone users typing in their PIN because face ID failed. And a fingerprint reader is just faster when I take my phone out of my pocket because I can put my finger on the fingerprint reader already when the phone is still in my pocket. So it is already unlocked once I look at it while with face ID I first have to hold it in front of my face. Also the fact that iPhones still don't have usb-c is so annoying. So these to me are two HUGE points for Android. Other than that I love iPhones and IOS.

Another thing after watching this movie - make thought experiment and switch android and iOS sides. iOS have to work on all that different CPU`s, be customisable, has to have gazilion different brands and tweaks. And Android? Few only google pixel phones, enormous company have time and money to make android perfect just to work on their cpu`s and stuff. Compare android and iOS is next to impossible due to their work areas, iOS is closed and apple have time and resources to make it best only for their own gear. Android have to work on everything that exists. Think about that. It`s like you have two cars and highway. One of them is every sporty car, low, fast, like it was born for highways. And other is not as fast, not as beautiful but it can also ride offroad, it can fly, and go underwater, and if you will compare those two only at the highway - well, second car would seem to be worse. Yes? And truth is that those vehicles are not for comparison. One guy will choose first one, other have different needs and he will be happy for having second car.

gee just two iphone fanboys really. I wouldn't find any of those software features useful.
As an Android user I can't really disagree with this video. However, what I would say is that Android is usually 90-95% of the way there in most cases, and its how important that ease of use is to you in terms of what you want to do. A bunch of the Apple stuff is convenience based, but has pretty similar equivalents all over Android, and usually for free. I wouldn't consider myself a power user by any stretch, but it's so much more convenient plugging an Android device into a PC for content creation than it is to get stuff off iPhones UNLESS you also have a Mac/iPad as your main computer. Similarly a bunch of the launchers/apps on Android do things I want more than the Apple equivalents with minimal-ish barriers to entry.   I think of them like houses to be honest - do you just want a nice new-build condo where everything is functional and just works, but potentially can be a bit flat. Or do you want a smaller/bigger house where you chop and change some of the rooms around to how you like. I think it always comes down to user-choice vs pick up and play.

This is such an open ended question with so many variables that I don't think this was a good way to try and answer it. What I took away from this is that they put a single iPhone against all Android phones and while some Android phones are better than the iPhone, there are many Android phones that are not as good, so the conclusion is that the Android average is lower and therefore the iPhone wins?!   There are so many phones manufacturers using Android and so many versions of Android that you can't use averages to draw a conclusion. I would have wanted them to be way more specific, i.e. pick a certain user group to focus on since different user types have different needs, pick only one phone out of each camp whether that be a flagship or entry-level, and be much more specific about the criteria for each category.   I feel like many of the categories they discussed, like camera and screen quality for example, had really good arguments for Android as the winner but the iPhone took it because Marques just preferred certain aspects of it. In fact, many of the arguments seemed to boil down to what the presenters preferred, instead of looking at it objectively.   There are also a lot of factors that just weren't considered here, another reason to be more specific with the comparison.

With how eco conscious they are, I would have 100% given that to android almost no question.   Because Android isn't as locked down it can be repurposed. Reduce, Reuse, Recycle and order matters.   Neither really "reduce" in this context, but Reuse is really important. There are so many projects someone who is eco conscious can use their old android for without that much technical knowhow. Like a quick google for "useful things to use an old android for" returns loads of lists full of interesting and not particularly difficult projects that allow you to utilise the less locked down nature of the ecosystem. Sure you can do some of these on an iPhone if there's an appropriate app built, but there is so much more customisation.   As an example, I use a very old android as a built-in smart display in my computer tower to display temps.   Recycling is good, but Reusing is better.  Also (this does play into eco a bit too), with android you have more choice. You can get an S22 Ultra if you want to get something that matches Apple's flagships, but you can also get phones that compete for entirely different needs than iPhones. So you're not limited to buying a big phone with an unreplacable battery and the glass sandwich design.
Smart Stylus support, usb c, foldable editions, max customization. These are all wins for android!!

I LIKE my S22 Ultra more so it gets more use, but I TRUST my iPhone more when it comes to overall longevity.   I admit that I upgrade my Android devices way more frequently because  of the features offered. When it comes to iPhones, the experience is reliable and consistent no matter which one you have, so I find no need to upgrade at all and usually keep it at home as a back up.  I can deal with some of Apple's restrictions like the inability to download  third party apps, but If ios offered some of the features of Android such as multitasking, better customization, and USB C, even a diehard Android user like me would find it hard not to ditch android altogether.

It would be my first iphone ever. I really love android, but these days, the performance is so close and every single reasons mkbhd said about the phone working without as many hiccups and being stable is whats really important. I have an s20 fe that has deteriorated so quickly. The camera always lags and hangs for along time when trying to use the quick lockscreen button, and then stutters and the shutter doesnt become available (potentially missing the shot). Then, when I want to edit and upload to social media, it bugs out and the quality sucks, and social media is too important these days for the type of quality my phone puts out lol. Regular photos are beautiful, but then the video SUCKS. Its shaky as hell and has weird microstutters and artifacts every so often. Its so bizarre. Ive been on android long enough (since nexus 5) to know that every android phone has some weird shit like this pop up at some point. Its such a shame, and I feel like the pixel line was the best chance at a premium andoird experience that could compete with apple. Now I plan on just getting an iphone as a main phone and possibly getting a budget pixel 6a or 7a or whatever comes out next as a private personal line on google fi. Finally I can say apple has enough customizations that I also think look a bit better than android widgets. The custom rom days are gone, and most android users want the same polished experience and hardware/software relationship on their androids that apple has with their phones. Pixel launcher and UI is great, but I just feel like Google's glory days are ending here. Google assistant is still amazing though, and Ill never use alexa or siri.

I will just share my opinion ok.  In Photography one should be tied  It is really depends on a user since it is either consistency, or creativity. When It comes to photography, as photographer, it will be always choose the creativity and flexible Camera. But as normal people, it is 50/50 choosing between having flexible Camera or The consistent Camera.  For the features, Iphone has some pretty usefull festures. Airdrop, shareplay, facetime. Those are usefull cuz that is how most people see it, the galaxy has those features too but they were not being noticed by many people. You can share play in the google duo same as the share play in Iphone. The google duo is also a facetime, but in Andoroid Version. And also the airdrop is great feature, but galaxy have same feature as the airdrop which is called, quick share and share link feature. There are chances that airdrop loses the quality of the image, even in imessage. But the quick share link is completely sharing the full quality of files consistently.  Those features of samsung and apple just works almost the same. The only big difference are, samsung features works in universal. Like it work on Iphone, and any other android device. Airdrop, shareplay, facetime only works on Iphone. They are only usefull since that's how the Iphone groups hype the iphone features. Quick Share link of samsung is even better than airdrop. You can quick share link to an Iphone, but you can't do airdroping file to android. Also, Airdrop is annoying, when you are playing games in your phone, there will be suddenly a poped up in the middle of the screen of an airdrop file from an annoying friend trying to annoy you while you are playing. Google duo is just works same as facetime, but the difference is, google duo is universal. It can be done in Iphone, and in any other android phone. Facetime is only on Iphone. Iphone maybe good at forcing people to move to iphone, but doesn't mean they are better.  When it comes to more useful simple feature, that is what Iphone is lack of. Why Can't apple have another back gesture for the right side of the phone? Apple just announce a landscape face id, while samsung with no notch can have a face recognition works well even in Up side down. Other simple usefull feature that Iphone doesn't have is clipboard.  It is a very simple feature to add in the keyboard and it is very usefull. Which you can copy and copy more text at once, and you can paste and paste them all at once in anywhere. You will not have to go back and forth between 2 apps just to copy and paste copy and paste....  Another simple thing that is simple useful feature that Iphone doesn't have is, secure folder. Iphone may have added security on the hidden pictures in their gallery app. But it is nothing compare on having the secure folder, not just hidden photos but, another hidden accounts, apps, and more... One more very simple thing to change in Iphone, it is not very big deal but, it may be deal breaker for others. It is how ios keep all the back gestures/buttons on the left side. Not many people are right handed, and not many people use 2 hands on their phone all the time. Their reachability feature is useless, one handed mode is a lot better in many reasons. Other thing that ios is still lacks on is, costumization, it is not simple feature as what samsung can do on costumization, but apple is a big company, come on apple it should be simple for you to add more of costumization on your devices. Other thing that apple should add to their iphones is, usb C. Apple can do it in their macbook and ipad. Why not in Iphone? Everyone knows what is USB C capable of compare to lightning port. Not just in fast charging but, also better connectivity in external devices.  I don't get what is the real reason why apple are so slow. Even just some simple thing like, adding numbers row in there keyboard couldn't be done. Typing a long wifi password that it is mixed with letters and numbers in Iphone is awful. Other simple feature that should be added on apple devices is, having to set up the volumes on specific apps. Like you can have it on galaxy which is very usefull to me since I do music while playing games sometimes. Or have multi task having youtube/video playing while playing games sometimes. It is very useful for me since I treat the multi tasking thing as a very useful feature. I can costumize the volume of the game to be shut up for a moment while I listen to something else that is playing in the background app. Also the very last simple useful feature that samsung has and that Iphone couldn't afford is wifi QR code. Wifi sharing in Iphone is good, but it only works in Iphone. Having someone who is not an Iphone user will not be able to recieve the wifi share from your Iphone. Samsung done it better with its QR code maker for the wifi. If you wanna share a wifi to others, have the QR code on your samsung and let them scan it for them to connect to wifi. Apple is a big company, and just some simple things that are very useful to add in their iphones, they couldn't just be done it.

Buyers of iPad Air and iPads pro line are quite fewer than budget iPad buyers and only iPhone owners who are still on only Lightning.

Super interesting video on a very hot topic! Love the two perspectives but personally disagree on a few things. Photography for me has been flawless on Pixel and I have spent enough time using different Pixels (not the 6 yet) to be pretty aware of the cameras and have a fairly perfect experience. I know the "look" of the photo, the best angles, lighting and modes for the IMX363 and can confidently take it out and get my desired photo. The other spot was eco consciousness. The fair phone is definitely there for that but if you actually see each company's overall approach Google is much further on a much larger scale than any smartphone company. Google does have resources from a much larger backing since it is mainly an advertising/software company and not a smartphone company so they do have more backing. The things Google has invented for a greener world are often on a scale never seen before. Final thing is integration which Google has worked on quitely with ChromeOS and Android now having a lot of the features (nearby share any file, send/recieve messages, calls on Duo, etc.) that used to be IOS + MacOS exclusives. Difficult topics with each point having very good arguments from both sides. Great vid, cool to see the take that large creators have on this.

For the camera comparison, considering the front facing camera, the reason why the notch is so big for all the camera technology on the iPhone is because the Face ID is way more accurate on the iPhone compared to android phones. The android considers your face in a flat manner compared to iPhone which can include depth and due to the technology to facilitate this the notch has to be there and the iPhone could recognise if e.g. a photo or plastic mask of your face  was just shown to the iPhone, the iPhone can detect that. In other cases not for security it uses machine learning to dictate different layers of photos for example your backdrop.
I'm a fan of both of you guys, but comparing iPhone and Android is a fundamentally flawed endeavor. Android is an operating system. The iPhone is hardware. A better apples to apples comparison (pun intended) would be iPhone to Pixel or iOS to Android.

Eco friendly factor.... Fair phone... Modular design of Android phones allow for better repairability.. Nothing else left to say.....   Performance factor.  in demanding game titles... Gaming phones actually win in terms of sustained fps...  Samsung and apple devices both down throttle 5-10 mins into the gaming session. Availability of game titles, android actually wins, Since you have access to multiple app stores and there's also APK installation.   Value for money is actually too subjective to compare... Since different people value different aspects.... If performance for money , android would win with redmagic7 or Poco phones.... But if you want camera performance for money it's a diff story.

sponsored by iphone
The most biased take ever. Well done guys.
A) The Lightning connector is FAR superior to USB-C! On a daily use of a charging cable, in the car, in the office, on the nightstand etc. That cable is unplugged and plugged back in repeatedly. USB-C uses very thin bent metal and the center of it is hollow for the mating end on the device to plug in, which allows for dust to invade the cable end and it wears out much quicker when it comes in contact with the plastic pin inside the device. Lightning cables don't have that problem because they don't have moving parts on the cable like USB-C. The iPhone side is a simple hole that's bi-directional and there's no plastic pin inside to snap off from repeated use like USB-C on the device itself. B) Apple devices were made specifically for Apple and work best with apple products and software. Which means, software developed on Apple works better.  C) IOS gets updates/upgrades often to keep up with the latest security breaches etc and to add new features to their devices. Sure, Android developers do it as well, but how often does AT&T or Verizon actually give you those updates and upgrades? They typically only give you what benefits them, and not you. Because if you dont have the latest Android OS like your friends, youll trade in your 1.5 year old phone for a new one just to keep up. And if you do choose to sideload the OS on your own from an APK, good luck getting support from your vendor when it wasn't approved by them for you to use it. D) iMessaging! It works even when there's no cell service as long as you have WiFi. Normal SMS doesn't work without an active cell connection. There are a lot of places where there is zero cell service

Yeahhh now shut up android fan boys
I can say weight in on this. I have owned an iPhone since the first week of it's release. I only now just switched to Android. I'll explain why I switched first.  For most people who purchase Android it is because of price, price, price. I have a flagship phone for just $400. How? It's last year's model. Android phones drop in price like crazy.  A few things really stand out on Android that I switched over specifically for. Android has LDAC Bluetooth. It's awesome. USB-C for audio as well is important. Fast charging is great, in screen finger print reader is awesome. Also battery life IS way better on Android if you get one with a large battery. Again for audio, when in the car, Android Auto is superior. You can change songs with voice on Google. Siri STRUGGLES with artists names and songs. Not to mention Street addresses.  The downsides: Switching to Android is a huge pain in the ass. It took me three weeks to setup my phone. It was not fun. Also what's with Visual Voicemail?? It's atrocious on Android. This was a feature Apple has solved a LONG time ago. One surprise is Android new messages app! It's actually good! The problem was that it wasn't installed on my phone. It was a third party app. Took me awhile to figure this out. I think that's gonna be the case for most people. To sum things up, if audio is your biggest use of your phone...the answer is easily Android. Go with Apple for ease of setup, and if taking videos is your top priority. (Android is fine at videos, but Apple kills it.)

I have a different interest in what phone is "best" than either of these two great reviewers do - and that is what phone can I flash the OS of my own preference on it, so that it does not by default "phone home" to a particular corporation (whether Google or Apple), and so that it is not stuck with a proprietary and closed off digital eco-system.  Given that Apple is thoroughly locked down, where as many Android phones can be flashed with Android Open Source Project variants (such as /e/, Calyx, Graphene, Arrow, Havoc, etc.) or Linux based mobile OS's (such as Ubuntu Touch, Sailfish, Plasma Mobile, Phosh, Mobian, etc.) - that's where I'm at.

I've used both Apple and Android phones. I'm going with Android. Apple does have some strong points, but in my experience Android charges faster of course with the proper charging brick as mentioned, with that being said, in some cases, Apple's battery lasts longer due to the fact that it has nowhere near the amount of features (reverse wireless charging, Bluetooth S-pen to name a few) and customizations that Android has, so of course this impacts battery performance in a lot of cases. As far as cameras are concerned, both are not too far apart as far picture and video quality, with that being said, It does depend on the user and what camera settings are selected during the taking of a pic or video. You can't go wrong with either phone. Just comes down to personal preference and the community you're already apart of, i.e. if you have a Tab S8 and Samsung Earbuds and USB Type-C cables already, I'm sure you'd get an Android. Same goes for the Apple community in having a Mac book and iPad with lightning cables lying around. Lol. Both Android and Apple phone's have a lot to offer and both are really good phones.

The problem with going with an average when talking abt iPhones and androids is that it inherently becomes unfair as you're taking the top of the line from the iPhone sicne that's all they offer, but averaging down on Android because we're starting at the top and increasing the sample size by going down. This means that no matter what category you go for it will always be averaged out to the iPhone since that has a far smaller sample size. What you guys should've done was take a few key android phones maybe 5 of them, and compare the iPhone to the average of those 5 specifically. This would've made for a far more fair comparison as we don't need to lessen the credit to android by going through all the cheap and failed phones or the extreme phones.
I'm android fun but with pixel 6 I feel like the more capable and existing android phone gets - the less stable it is. If iphone 14 will finally get type C and a small front camera cutout - I will switch!
I feel this is a pretty unfair comparison.  Apple makes both the iPhone and iOS, which is designed for iPhone.  Yet Android is an OS for a multitude of phones.  It's as silly as comparing an Xbox or PS5 to PC.  Both Xbox and PS5 have OS, hardware, etc specific to those products, yet across the world there are so many PC configurations you can't really compare them.  Same with Android and iPhone.  You can't compare a single manufacturer with only 4 or 5 phones, most high end, to a slew of hundreds of Android phones.  A better comparison, IMO, which has already been done to death, are at price points.  What does the iPhone SE offer compared to most popular Android phones in that price point, what does the iPhone 13 range offer compared their popular android price points?  That makes more sense IMO.

I believe the main difference between both ecosystems is control. In Apple devices, although some of their features are miles ahead of Android with their garden-walled ecosystem, those features often take away control from the users. It lures them into the Apple ecosystem which in many cases can drain their wallets, and those features make it hard to get out of the ecosystem. When I hold an iPhone, I lack the feeling that the phone is mine. Sure, you can stop other apps from tracking your data and having control of your data, but in some aspects, it can simply be perception. What is stopping Apple from tracking your data? The end-user has given away a lot of information to Apple, often more than to other companies due to the controlled perception, but you will never fully know if Apple is tracking your data. Sure, you know that Google & Facebook is taking data from you which can make you more cautious, but you don't know if Apple is, and many users think that Apple doesn't take any data. The reason why the iPhone has all these features and can heavily optimize the select devices that they have is that they have control over what you do, while Android gives you more options like sideloading.

It still amazes me how we have gotten so far off the beaten path over a "phone". Primary function: Communication. Call, text/sms, emails. If it handles those without issue then the phone is fulfilling it's purpose. Second is durability and battery life. At this point the iPhone blows away anything Android has. The overall performance, function and longevity with iPhones is what "value" truly is. The fact that vanity has played such a major role the past few years is bewildering to say the least. That is the least important aspect of any product, yet it has such a major impact as of late. Most intelligent people will put a CASE on their investment to protect it. Paying $1000 + for a phone would be silly not to. That would be like driving a 100K M-Benz and not having insurance on it. Android is good for the vanity crowd. But true value, functions and durability goes to the iPhone.

Same goes for Android, especially if you're going the Samsung route and you've picked up their watch and bought into their services, it's doubtful you're looking to move on.   Both OS's are very mature at this point, so it really comes down to what ecosystem you're already invested in.

In truth there will never be a time thatâ€™s good to compare iPhoneâ€™s with Android phones. They are differing experiences deliberately.  Android is choice, openness and customisation whereas iOS is simple, stable (Generally speaking. Nothingâ€™s perfect.), secure with a powerful ecosystem behind it. As an Apple device user in general, an iPhone is a no-brainer for me. At the same time, when I have used an Android device in the past the strength has always been to make that phone entirely me. Down to almost the smallest detail.   A person will either be an Android person or an iPhone person. It is about the individual. Both offer equally strong experiences depending on the person. I am not going to lie but I really don't agree with MKBHD. I know these are subjective, but for example using an Android is definitely more fun than an iPhone. For example, when I get a new phone, I like to a spend a good hour or two looking at settings, because it is exciting. Oh, I can disable pop-up notifications from every single app! Oh, I can straight up block an app's permissions! Oh, I can customize how I want my taskbar or my hotbar! These are the small things that make an android legendary. On an iPhone, it's boring. The settings are same for every device, the looks and usually the options too. The cameras are also so much better on Android than iPhone. It's just more exciting. Like, you aren't just seeing "Video", "Camera" and "Ultrawide" options on an android. You are seeing almost everything. And if you can't you have a "more options" tab. I just like it more. The issue may be less of "which is actually better," and more one of recognizing that only a few years ago Apple embodied the pinnacle of consumer tech and innovation. In 2022, at least as far as the mobile sector, Apple seems to be copying Android, relies upon Samsung for the best OLED panels, and still attempts to dictate to consumers that less is more by aspiring to the abolition of ports, removing touch ID, effectively demanding that we use  Face ID (no thanks, touch ID worked fine even before the mask mandates), and still balking at a stylus. Apple's sentiment might assuage the need for some sort of aesthetic purity as envisioned by cubicle dwellers in Cupertino, but out here in the real world we love ports, expandable memory, the stylus, and yes, power bricks included with the phone. RIP Steve Jobs and long live Samsung!

Especially right now it's very important to me to be available for calls and mails because of my applications. I also noticed that the vibration of my alarm was getting so weak that I didn't even hear it in the morning and had to buy an alarm clock in order to wake up on time otherwise I'd oversleep. I never had such issues with my old phone. I always noticed the notifications, calls, alarms etc. I never overslept with my old phone only using the vibration. On my new phone, even if I turn on the volume and chose a song or a sound to wake me up, there's no sound coming out of my phone. Now that I've also got my Galaxy Watch, I could never use a phone that doesn't have a headphone jack because you can only keep it connected with one device. 1:49 really nice little detail of a dent in the on screen caption
As a lifetime Android user, I accept that Apple's ecosystem is extremely strong and thorough, and if I had enough money when I was young to buy an iPod I'd probably be an iPhone user right now.   The key features with Android devices is flexibility, transparency, and a larger scope of compatibility. Flexibility: I can tinker with my android in any manner that I require without having to jailbreak/root it, and if I want to do those things its much easier to undo. Additionally, desktop emulation of an Android is MUCH easier than an Apple product, meaning I can save tons of battery life and have graphic higher fidelity by using a PC that I will always have anyway. Transparency: I can plug in my android to any computer and dig through the files, manually find what I need, and essentially use it as a hard drive that I can take with me. Compatibility: Every modern Android device can be charged with a usb-c cable. The same usb-c that I can use with my Nintendo Switch, or Oculus Quest, or even a modern Macbook.

Ok so we are going iphone vs average android flagship  Display: draw, android tends to have the better raw display but iphone makes better use of what it has  Performance: draw, most users wouldnt notice much difference but apple does have less rough edges in day to day. In return for that though, android has much more you can do to make use of that performance.   Battery: android, most users arent power users and can last a day. So the difference is indeed the faster charging which android pretty much destroys in.  Photography: android, some more rough edges that happen rarely shouldnt be enough to tip it to iphone. I mean that should be part of the software reliability not the photography. Android has clear superior results.   Videography: iphone, sony does take better videos (and photos too) but we are looking at average android flagships so iphone.   Software reliability: iphone no question. Ive been using Android for 10 years, decided to buy the iPhone 13 Pro, but kept my S21 Ultra for a while.. And to me, Android still the best, found some issues on iOS tha drove me nuts, however there are yes some things that I wish Android had like iOS, but overall the experience on iOS was underwhelming.   Back gesture on iOS for an S21 Ultra user is a nightmare, you have to swipe it precisely horizontally, the notch distract me a little (I guess 14 will solve this), I got tired just of thinking on how to organize the apps on Home Screen, and to add icons at the bottom of the home page you have to have 3rd party app to create a transparent widget.  Haptics on iPhone are top notch, Samsung has improved a lot over the past years, but still some level behind Apple`s.  Another thing that I noticed is that some input lag or low touch sensitivity on iPhone, scrolling on apps like instagram, twitter is very choppy and slow, even considering that both displays are 120hz capable, my S21 Ultra is way snappier and responsive.

for some reason this discussion sound highly bias.
Not fair guys. I get it, iPhone is great but the S22 Ultra, in my opinion, kinda embarrasses the iPhone. I love the productivity I get using the split-screen and the floating windows that I can drop down anytime from the customizable sidebar, and the S-pen guys? the number of things that the S-pen does from off-screen note-taking to clicking pics, to the options to copy and snip and translate stuff using Air actions, and writing directly on search bars over typing something, and it's so helpful when wearing winter gloves. Samsung Notes app alone is a lifesaver, for both note-taking, sketching, recording lecture audio while taking down notes etc. Today I forgot to charge my Watch 4 and all I did at the office was turn on my Wireless Power Share on the S22 Ultra and kept my watch on top of my S22 Ultra and it juiced up to 40%. I do that for my Galaxy buds too. The advantages seem to be endless. What about the Always-on Display? with this feature I 'Never' stop to see my Lock-screen, it's more like going straight from 'Always-on display' to the 'Home screen', I hardly pick up my phone or tap it to see my dual-zone time or to see if I have a new notification. What about the excellent fingerprint reader? it's so funny to see iPhone users trying to pick up their phones from the desk to unlock it using the face ID, and don't even mention the face mask problem, that's sad. My wife has an iPhone 13 pro and it's sad that the limited features and the options for file folder management, data transfer and all feel so restricted. I think IPhone's airdrop feature is amazing, but I do get around using Samsung Flow with no major issues. And the biggest of all is the Type C port that the iPhone does not give you! Of course, nothing beats the swipe/translate/voice input on the Google keyboard and nothing compares to saying "hey google". I am not big on making videos and not big on social media either and so I don't really care much about how quick the camera is, but the other day at the office from the 11th floor I zoomed in and snapped pictures of cars parked over 500 mteres across the street and even the registration plates of those cards were legible, I bet the iPhone can't do half of that. I also feel the S22 ultra is much easier to hold and it brings down the menus to your fingertip, also the convenience of pulling down the notification bar from anywhere on the home screen. The problem for Samsung is that they have too many low-end phones that don't do well and those phones set the majority impression of the brand. Pro tip: in order to maximize the screen real estate on my S22 ultra, I hid my Navigation bar and use Swipe gestures to swipe from the bottom and sides, this thing allows you to swipe back from any side edges of the screen so literally you don't have to reach to the top or the bottom.

This is not how you make an objective comparison. Android is an operating system and therefore cannot be compared to an iPhone which is the combination of both an operating system and hardware. To make an objective comparison you would either have to compare the latest version of Android to the latest version of iOS or you would need to compare an Android handset that is in the same price range and class as an iPhone.

In terms of battery life in my eyes it is a win for android. I didn't had an iPhone yet but I had the P30 Pro and the Pixel 6 and both are absolute incredibly when it comes to the battery. With all other phones I struggled to get through a day but with those 2 phones I check the percentage once in the morning and then basically forget about it for the rest of the day. Even though both phones don't really have more battery then other phones. (Means that it is 90% a software thing how long your phone can last.) But the P30 pro was even more crazy. When fully charged (normally I keep my phone between 20 and 80 percent) it could even survive the next day when I forgot to charge it over night.  And that's the next point: Charging  The Pixel 6 has just an average charging speed but the P30 pro was fast. 30 minutes could fill almost half the battery. That phone charged so quick that I stopped charging over night and just plugged it in when it started to run low (under 20 or 15 %). I never needed to charge that phone for longer than an hour.  The Pixel 6 isn't as fast but that's because the fastest charger is in general the one cable and plug combination that came with the phone and the 6 comes without a plug.

I think the point that was made about how Android still has options that cater to small niches, while Apple has clear staples of its experience, is a clear win for Android. Apple's offerings there still largely only matter to people who are within the Apple ecosystem, and require other users to also be a part of that ecosystem to function at their fullest. The fact that Android still caters toward small niches of people who need a particular feature of the software to remain active makes them far more backwards compatible, more openly compatible with other ecosystems, and overall improve the broader experience for more users.

There are 2 reasons why I like Android over iPhone. First, I am no longer invested in the Apple ecosystem. Because of that, Android just communicates with my windows computer better than an iPhone will. I also acknowledge that iPhone communicates better with Mac than Android, but as stated, I don't own any Apple products anymore. Second, the Apple app store has much more restrictive ToS than Google Play. Now, I get the point of having a more restrictive ToS, but that stricter ToS prevents apps like NVIDIA's GeForce Now app from ever reaching Apple's app store... unless Apple relaxes their ToS. Now, before you go bitching about being fine with a looser ToS, I believe in a few things. First, as long as you are smart about what you let on your phone, regardless of which operating system you use, there is a lesser chance of installing malware. Second, while very much less likely to include malware, you can still get it on an Apple device through an app. Just because it is very difficult and won't last long doesn't mean it is impossible.

I don't agree on the eco consious part.  You gotta factor in the longevity of the device. iPhones out of the box come with at least 5 years of updates, but so do Samsung phones now. And if you're phone doesn't get official updates anymore, at least on android you can install custom roms on it to extend it even further for at least a couple of good years. Also, the android phones are generally more repairable, with more parts available and less likely to have software lockups if you replace a part with a 3rd party one.   The port is also usb-c which means if you don't get a charger with it anymore you probably don't have to spend more money to get yet another box shipped to you, and if you do have to buy a charger, at least it's a universal standard which means you got a lot more options from competitors and the like.

The thing I hate about "carbon neutral" is that to become carbon neutral, most companies just buy what is called carbon credits. That basically means a company donates money to a startup or another company who are doing things to reduce carbon in the atmosphere and reduce carbon emissions in various ways such as more wind power or making electric cars more affordable and accessible.

Many people forgot one thing, that is the Time Apple has and others don't have. Apple already an established premium brand created a hype and released it's first iPhone that is of course because of Steve Jobs. Remember people went mad over a phone from Apple back in 2007 even it lacks lot of features compared to Androids then. People even don't know what is an app bought the iPhones just to show off that they got a premium Apple iPhone. Chinese and Indians who always follow US supported this trend and Apple got instant recognition world wide. Samsung which is in market already has no premium brand recognition like this. Every other company like HTC, LG, Blackberry etc lost in market because of this unexpected trend created by Apple. Samsung survived by some innovation like using Oleds, software features etc on their mobiles. Google just ignored this trend and still is. So, this gave Apple lot of ample time to release features slowely without any rush as their market was increasing even iPhones  lack lot of basic features like filesystem, forceful dependency on iTunes etc whereas Samsung like companies has to rush to implement features in no time to compete with Apple. This resulted in lakluster performance from Android team especially quality control from Samsung whereas Apple enjoying taking good amount of time to refine it's eco system. It took Apple to catch up with Samsung OLEDs and punch holes ten years of time. Apple never cared about losing the market because of lacking features as people never bought iPhones for features. 90% of the people still buy iPhones to showoff. This gave Apple years of time to slowely implementing features with zero issues. I use both iPhones and Samsung because I love some innovations from Samsung. And the quality control from Samsung and Google is still bad compared to Apple. If Google and Samsung concentrate on quality taking good time like refining Android, Apps and hardware issues, camera quality etc sure people will gradually support Android eco system too. I personally love Samsung mobiles but forcefully buy Apple iPhones because undoubtfully they are best. But, monopoly is dangerous for end users, so I wish Android team give serious competition to Apple in future.

Reliability being a draw is the biggest shocker.  Unless something has changed in the past few years, since during that time I've been using iOS exclusively, Android's OS reliability is noticeably worse than that of the iPhone.  A big part of reliability, IMO, doesn't even have to do with the OS itself.  Even if we said Google and Apple both have equal system-wide reliability (I would argue against that, but say we concede that), you have to consider the reliability of the apps within each OS.  I have just found that the same apps usually work better more often on the iPhone for whatever reason.  Maybe that's unfair since it has more to do with third party developers rather than Apple vs Google, but it must be a factor one considers in overall reliability, IMO.  Anyway, this was a great video.  And I'm glad it's not one of the overly-perfected videos we normally get from this channel (although the content is stellar, don't get me wrong; anytime you get MKBHD or Arun giving smartphone opinions, you watch that video!).  That leads me to believe you are taking seriously your pledge to improve your mental and physical wellbeing.  And that, that is awesome :)
The screen on iPhone is nowhere near better. Nor was it tie.  -Samsung at least have better screen such as AMOLED, which is a higher quality than normal OLED -Also higher resolution, even if you don't care that it's a little higher, Samsung still has more pixel per inch.   Performance and Battery were fair. iOS tends to be more optimized and no one really uses multitask and that. Ram doesn't really matter for iPhones since their OS is optimized. But USB type C is better. It charges faster when you need it. (but it wears the battery down faster), but there are options to get the fullest of your battery life in settings where the phone slow down the charging when it hits 80%.  Camera- I guess iPhones cameras are good since their AI is smart and can make the photos look good even though their camera megapixels are low, but I'd say that Samsung cameras aren't bad, not that it should've lost to Apple's camera, Samsung megapixels are high, and their zooms are useful too, might not use it every time but still uses it quite often. And their AI aren't too far away from Apple's. But in Mrwhostheboss video for camera test. Samsung won. So I have no idea why it's different here.  Software reliability- You can make vibrate motor higher, and I think both phone can be annoying from time to time.  Software features-Both have their own things,  Samsung DEX- I don't personally use it, but for some people it's helpful.  iMessage, FaceTime and Airdrop- It's only important for those who uses iPhones, like I use messenger or Snapchat to do the exact same thing. But Airdrops are actually useful for quick share instead of sharing links and that through apps. (Not a huge point tho)  But one thing about Android thats amazing is that I can just go on the internet and download anything, like Youtube Vanced, Snaptube, Adguard (iOS have it as well, but its just for browser whereas on android its for apps as well), and many things that are much better to have.

Great video and so fun to watch. However I felt like this could have been a direct comparison of iPhone flagships vs Samsung/Pixel/Huawei flagships or iOS vs Android, as opposed to iPhone vs Android. Although it doesn't seem like there's any difference (because iPhones are the only phones that run iOS), notice how they kinda had to compare the  best features from multiple phones to the only (premium) offerings of iPhones available. Of course, its not their fault that they had to do it this way, but it would be fairer to people trying to make practical choices if the overall software performances of the two OSs were highlighted over the hardware components since each Android phone handles the OS differently and most users are really only going to be able to afford one flagship.  That way, the comparison would be a lot less assymetrical and could also help us in the audience who  really want to see a direct comparison. To be fair still, most people already know what they like and are just here for the entertainment so this is just a rambling suggestion I guess ðŸ˜‚.

Great video, I enjoyed it! Comparing these two device categories is a difficult task, and in the end it does indeed just come down to preference. For me, I am a computer scientist and I prefer total control over my device. However, that control can come with the price of complexity and, if you don't know what you're doing, unreliability.  The reality is that most people want something that is easy to use out of the box, and Apple has really pinpointed this as one of their main goals. But if you really want control of your device (without jailbreaking), Android will always beat Apple in that regard. The way I see it, Apple is very single-purpose oriented (do it our way, it works), while Android tends to be general-purpose oriented (do it your way, if it works is up to you).

The entire premise for this video is flawed imo. It should be android versus IOS not android versus iPhone. If you go with android versus IOS then you could come up with an entirely different set of features that will tilt this entirely in the favor of android.  If you go with Android versus IOS then the simple difference is support for multiple devices, wearables and form factors,  stylus support, external monitor support, works with external docks like nexdock, wide range of camera hardware support to suite individual shooting styles and use cases and accessories support. Also android support more hires audio codes. Still offers support for devices with dual SIM and SD card expansion slots.

Being more of an Android guy myself I can pretty much hear the Apple fanboys sharpening their sticks while I'm typing, but nevertheless, I can feel the bias reach through the screen and grab me by the throat all throughout this video, so I feel the need to address a few things. I'm not one of those Android users who's got some personal feud with Apple. I do recognize that iPhones do have their advantages, if not for everybody, then at least for certain types of people. Personally, I can't see those outweigh the advantages of Android - which is why I use Android phones - but to each their own.   This review, though, was substantially skewed in favour of Apple. I mean, it's easy to modify the playing field so it leans towards one side or the other by choosing certain categories or specific brands or phones. It happens all the time. But in this video, they couldn't not give points to Apple for pretty much anything, even if the discussion went in favor of Android. And some of the points they brought up, heck, I had the feeling an Apple rep was standing behind them with one hand on a paycheck and the other on a loaded gun. I know MKBHD leans towards Apple. But up until now, at least on this channel the reviews seemed unbiased to me. That changed with this video. It was pretty clear who was the boss when it came to calling shots and who just caved in and announced a tie when even the discussion went in favor of Android. I'm really sorry, but to me, that's not a neutral analysis. That's advertisement.   Hopefully this was an anomaly and videos like this won't become the norm on this channel. I know, losing a single sub doesn't mean anything to a YouTuber of this magnitude, so I'm not gonna try and make a useless "threat" in that direction, but reading these comments, it's pretty clear that I am not the only one who noticed a certain bias, and I wouldn't wanna see the reputation of this channel suffer from future lopsided analyses.   Just my 2 cents.

Overall in general Android is better. However some companies using Android are getting just as bad as Apple. In general Android is more open, more customizable, able to be better secured, has more choice, and more pro right to repair.  However as time goes on companies like Samsung and Google have become more like Apple. Goggle has gone out of its way to make newer Pixel models less right to repair friendly. Samsung disables the camera if you unlock the bootloader to install a custom rom. Things like these are taking Android backwards.   People should be able to do what they want with the products they buy, get the parts to fix those products, and either fix it themselves or decide who they want to let fix it. It shouldn't matter if the product is an Apple phone, a Tesla car, or a Cuisinart coffee maker.

Iphone vs Android is a very hard thing to do. Android simply has too many brand exclusive features that isn't available on all Android phones.. Iphone is more consistent on features since it is a single brand. As a really hardcore user who regualarly unlocks bootlaoder, root or flash custom roms, undervolts & overclock the cpu.. android phones are a must to  me. Also, I use some really obscure third party apps from random places or developers which I simply cannot find apple alternatives. One more thing is most apps cannot be geoblocked on android since you can just download the app from third party stores. Fast charging is cool, I don't need crazy fast but i want at least 45w charging or 20mins for 50% of the battery. Value wise, apple is worse if you talk about reparability. If you talk about how long you can use a device, apple kind of wins since it has 5 years of update policy which is ahead of all android phones. This doesn't matter as much if you know how to flash custom roms which is what I did for most of my android phones. Photography wise, I am an average user so even a mid-range camera meets all my needs. The accessory is much cheaper for android phones too, USB-C cables are cheaper and works for most devices I use.
Multiwindow split screen is super important to me and I use it everyday. As well as a good and proper one handed mode not that joke of reachability mode on the iphones.
I personally prefer android
Most none reviewers basically consumers consider the S22 Plus superior as the S22 Ultra is supposedly overpriced for what it offers with poor battery life don't know how true that is though.
Android has nearby share by the way which is excellentl.  A serious problems for Android is that you can't send photos or files to your computer because PC's don't have nearby share.

Years ago I never imagined myself switching to an iPhone because it felt too "restricting" but here I am years later and I don't think I could ever go back to android. IOS just feels so polished, well made and premium. Where Android to me always feels "rough around the edges" and I always feel like I'm using some kind of test software.
One thing that i wanted to add here is that Apple has an amazing optimization team not just for the software but hardware as well,  but that's what you get from a company that only sells a single phone and hardware. Android is so hard to talk about because there is like more then 50 manufacture's that use the open software to make phones, EACH company would have to employ the same optimization's team apple has to make android as good if not better. Google and the pixel line leverages the full use of the operating system and all its optimization's because their the first party developer of the OS like apple is of their OS. Same goes for the apps from 3rd parties, they work so well with iPhone because the devs only need to make it work with one OS just different sizes (iOS, iPad OS, Watch OS, and Mac OS are basically one OS just scaled up or down for the hardware but are all based off one master OS).   In the end this video did one thing for me: opened my eyes to see how Apple is more or less catching up for the majority user and more better understand why people are such die hard fans of the OS and eco system, but for me alas im still a power user, my s20 ultra is always in split-screen, pop out window, i use my pen for notes, editing photos and as a shutter button when talking large group photo's, the phone also is the better hotspot phone (meaning i can connect like 15 or 20 devices to my phones wifi which is crazy), pass thru wifi hotspot as well super useful for not giving people your real wifi password.   I'll admit Dex and Bixby are useless, i have a loptop with good battery, to many desktops so i really have no use for my phone acting like a computer and Bixby is only so good at basic tasks. Google assistant is the ONLY way to go, i use that more then i talk to actual humans lol timers, calculations, conversations of units, planning trips, calling people, texting people, turning on and off system features. Sure all the others can do that as well, even bixby BUT it goes one further, google controls my house as well, lights, heating, window blinds etc. Apple has home assistant but Siri is cumbersome and boarder line useless as well (see bibxy for example).  Overall I would like to run iOS in my hands and see how it feels again, my last iPhone was a Steve Jobs creation and is almost the only reason im exclusively android now, I DO NOT LIKE HOW TIM COOK IS RUNNING APPLE AND WILL BOYCOT THE COMANY TILL I DIE! end of rant :) have a wonderful day if you read ANY of this lol LOVE YOU!

Really Disappointed this video...ðŸ’”
I kind of agree with the score, and I've been using Apple for the past couple of months after changing from the OnePlus 5 and I honestly can't wait to come back to Android. Small things, like you, can fit more on a screen, and put the icons wherever you want (especially with a big screen, having the most used apps at the bottom of the screen is super useful for me), putting this one more app in the dock in Android vs iPhone, for the same reasons as before. Google keyboard is SO MUCH better, especially if you're using more than one language. On iPhone, I need to constantly change the language for it not try to fix my mother language words into English and vice versa, and on google it just detects the language I'm using from the installed languages I got; also after a couple of months of using I have the feeling like the iPhone keyboard didn't learn anything about, and Google just knows what words I'm using and auto-correct is giving me the words I want when on iPhone is the exact opposite, it's just messing up my sentences all the time. And I know I can install google keyboard on my iPhone, but it just doesn't work in some apps for some reason, like Facebook messenger, which I'm using daily. Text editing is horrible on iPhone as well: on Android, I was just tapping in the middle of the word and it was letting me edit exactly where I tapped, whereas on iPhone tapping is hit or miss, sometimes it doesn't do anything, or it's selecting the whole word, or lands in a random place. You need to hold a spacebar and move around slowly, which is such a slow process compared to Android. Also writing with one finger (kind of Swift functionality) is only available in a couple of languages on iPhone (I have no idea why), whereas on Android I can use it with any language. Here's my little rant on the daily activities, that just break the iPhone experience for me ðŸ˜

Android phones don't use more RAM because apps are less efficient, it's because Android apps use the Java Virtual Machine (JVM) which means that it just takes more RAM. When it comes to games, both are compiled into native byte code which means that both use around the same amount of RAM.

No fancy stuff basically.    Android represents the more creative type users who don't want to be bound. Customization and more complication in the long run, but overall creative types who don't want to be bound to system rules, modify and develop. Smart, creative but slightly messy.  I used to be an iPhone user, i literally felt my hands were tied on what i could do, I felt limited, little customization, root file access or such. As an android user i felt free. Unlimited. Not bound to the rules of the ecosystem of the OS. The phones just kept evolving and getting better design and hardware wise.

Are things that Apple locks you in really worth calling "features"? I think Android should win this category, simply because it is much more flexible than Android and allows you to do a lot more things. For example: * changing many parts of the OS, like the launcher, keyboard, browser, lock screen * installing apps from outside the Play Store * full access to the file system * use it to do things you would traditionally do on a computer. You can do crazy things like coding, running all kinds of VMs and emulators. You can do all sorts of crazy automation with things like Tasker, like automatically opening the garage door when a message that contains a certain thing arrives.   Android is more like "here's a set of tools that you can use to do whatever you want". iOS is more like "these are the things you're allowed to do and how you can do them".
Biggest Takeaway for me is both of them are using Samsung Android phones and rate iPhone better. I prefer Android.

I only had an iPhone for a year.  It was a 12 Pro, so no 120hz refresh.  I moved back to Android because I was bored. Having the Pixel 6 Pro for 9 months, I now appreciate iOS. I miss the easy camera, snappy everything, apps always working & being better versions of their Android counterparts,  the way the battery charges & its longevity, Apple support, the mute slider, & everything just generally working how it's supposed to work.  Things I don't miss are lack of customization, Settings being an app, some settings being hidden or in odd places, how Apple handles notifications, Siri, no YouTube PiP,  and not being able to use most of the Apple exclusive features because no one I know owns an iPhone. I use Google assistant multiple times a day.  I used Siri often, but it usually was twice the work as it wouldn't understand me or couldn't get the results I wanted. After my 2 years with my Pixel are up, I'll either go back to Samsung or try iPhone again. The iPhone 15 will be a new design, but I doubt Siri or customization will have improved at all. The determining factors will be whatever irritates me more at the time of purchase.
I switched to the iPhone 13 pro last week. This is my first ever iPhone in my 27 years of existence. I must say it is quite refreshing to change and the app optimizations are drastically better than on android. I still love android but Iâ€™m happy I switched right now.

My biggest pet peeve from iOS is lack of background tasks, apps stop running in background completely, so if you have long running task like a download, upload or video editing running, you need to make sure that app remains in the foreground and phone doesn't locks until the task is completed, else the task fails. On Android this works great, since even if the app is pushed to background the app continues running it as a service and one can see the progress from the notification center. On iOS even something like a battery low pop up or swiping down notification center puts app in the background, the other day I lost a game since I got a battery low pop up and that caused the game disconnected from the  internet, this is just crazy. I wonder how come more people don't find it annoying specially tech youtubers who would be facing this scenario regularly.

You can't really compare Android and IOS  in the hardware aspect of things since Android runs on millions of different devices with different specs and iOS only runs on IPhones.
I think usb-c is another huge win for Android. being able to charge everything from laptop to phone to speaker with the same cable is game changing
The dual-app feature on Android is something I personally use all the time, and would immediately miss if I were to switch to iPhone (too few Android users know about it and use it imo). Floating windows is something I also use a lot, where you can have an app window that is essentially floating on top of everything else and can be minimised (you can open up a lot more than just 2 windows as well) it's actually a very cool feature you've probably never seen before, look it up even if you're an iPhone user, it's quite interesting lol.  Such "power features" and things like file system access, is why I prefer Android. So in the end it's always up to the specific user and their needs, which is what determines which platform is "better".

3:00 That's not something for debate, it's an architecture problem. Android is based in java, which means the apps run through a virtual machine, which consumes a fuckton of RAM, while iOS is basically C, which in simple terms goes almost right through to "machine language". That's why iPhones are more expensive, but at the end of the day are better, you pay for a cutting edge Software/OS experience.
I use my smartphone as a pc for work - split screen, floating apps so i just cannot use an iphone, but for more casual use i will use an iphone.

The list goes on, point being, if you're truly looking for the best of the best in a specific category there will always be an android that will win against the iPhone. However some people just like the comfort and simplicity of an iPhone and that's ok, iPhones are great phones, but if you want the best of the best and money isn't an issue go android. I had a 24 hour day
Hi Arun! This is a great collaborative effort! Well done. I really enjoyed it. As many commenters have expressed, I also think the comparisons were skewed.  If you had compared a specific flagship Android phone with a specific flagship Apple phone, it would've been more objective.  Comparing an entire Android ecosystem to a very different Apple ecosystem makes for far too many generalizations that scientifically render the comparisons extremely biased.  Yes, all your points and Mark's were valid, and I think I understood where you were both coming from. I think. Nevertheless, you both hit the bullseye of the dartboard with your collective assertion that one's choice of one ecosystem over the other is a matter of preference.   However, I wouldn't compare all the Mercedes Benz vehicles ever made to all the Teslas ever made. There are just too many variables and differences to account for that such a comparison would not only be unfair, but illogical.   Could factors such as fragility and durability, ease of maintenance and repairs, and the availability of parts (to mention a few) been included for a more detailed and objective discussion? Probably. You guys seemed to speak from your very privileged (no offense intended) perspectives.   To illustrate, when was the last time you decided not to get a phone because you couldn't afford it and not because it didn't feel great in your hand or because you preferred certain features on a different phone?  That's the perspective from which I think you both addressed the points discussed. That's not bad in itself, it's just what it is...your personal experiences and perspectives. And that's valuable. That's why we keep coming back.    Regardless of the flaws in the baseline premise that the Android and Apple ecosystems can be effectively compared, the product of your collaboration was absolutely beautiful to see. I'm not sure if this was your first time working with Mark, but I'm impressed nonetheless. Here's to more great collaborations! Job well done.

With regards to the RAM / battery / etc. it's not a fair comparison - keep in mind that Apple develops a lot of their own hardware including the CPU, as well as their own OS.  This means both hardware and software are gonna be highly optimised to work really well with less resources.  With Android there's huge diversity of hardware and software so it makes more sense to err on the side of caution and go with more hardware resources rather than less.

There are things I really like about android phones and there are things I really like about the iPhone. At this point, whatever you pick is personal preference as I don't see one as being far superior to the other.   Yes, app experience and iMessage are certainly better on iPhone. The setup process was so smooth and the quality of life features are very nice.  Android has more flexibility and bleeding edge tech that make it really fun for people like me to experience. Also I really enjoy Google Assistant. That is so nice compared to Siri.   For now I'm sticking with iPhone but I imagine I'll go back to Android in the future. Keep things fun!

Most newer chips just increases power consumption to deliver more performance which a really bad trend.

Hot take: I honestly think that MKBHD is kinda biased. No hate btw, I still very much like him, but lately no matter what, he sides with one brand/thing. Now for this example I choose to use Android vs IOS situation, since it's more relatable for most people. When there is any discussion about these or comparisons, he always sides with Apple. Not that it is a bad thing of course, I agree, there are things that Apple does better than most brands do. But here is where the problem starts to rise. Lets say that there is a feautre on Android that is absoluteley superior to anything else, for some reason he always goes for Apple. Now, I understand, people do have their prefrences, but come on, really? He literally acts like Apple is paying him for saying these, yet he misses all the useful information to give, or do useless comparisons. Its like saying "-my phone can zoom!" and saying "-well, why not get closer instead of zooming?" kind of situations where its even stupid to bring such arguments to the table. I feel like I cannot trust his words anymore, since it looks like he is purposely disregarding other brands to show one is superior over the other. If you closely watch his videos, you can see that this has became more and more obvious over time. Keep in my people, this is how I see it, and these are my views and opinions. Either way, I'm open for debates.

Samsung has the incredibly powerful Good Lock app which allows for ridiculous customisation and endless list of features. Some of these customisations would not be possible in other OEMs without rooting or jailbreaking. It also allows for extreme customisation of the lock screen which makes iOS 16 customisation of the lock screen look like a baby. So, in terms of customisation and features, Samsung just blows Apple out of the water. But Marques has rightly said that it is much easier to customise the iPhone. To customise a Samsung, you really have to dig into the settings but you can still do a lot more here. Also for AirDrop, you have Snapdrop for Android, for SharePlay, you have a feature inside of Google Duo which does the same and there is also the highly underrated Samsung and Windows ecosystem, albeit the Apple ecosystem is much more seamless.
Little criticism: You only compared the flagships in the comparison  - thats where apple shines , but not the budget phones, where android usually  shines. Also there are a lot of other aspects, like that the battery degrades faster with apple, which plays a roll in a lot of these categories. Another aspect was that it wasnt very clear what are you comparing, sometimes it was a direct comparison to the latest Samsung, or to a gaming phone, and the software is nearly at every android phones different, you compared the camera of an â€androidâ€ phone with another system on top, but when comparing the software  you just compared plain android. I think this video was very subjective, you couldve mentioned this more clearly. But overall a very good and entertaining video, I like them a lot.

Western countries like US and UK it would make sense why iPhone would be more preferred.   Most of the people there uses an iPhone already and are locked within the eco-system which makes you care for features such as iMessage, Airdrop and Facetime. Most of my friends don't even use an iPhone so all those features would be useless. For those friends I have that use an iPhone, they couldn't really utilize these things and they are literally using alternative apps just like us Android users because no one here send texts or chats in regular messaging apps.   We either use Messenger, What's App, or even Discord instead, and that applies to our friends that use an iPhone. Always nice to stir the Apple vs. Android sides .. . However - in my opinion, they are pretty much the same for a normal person. For me, it is all about design. - For that, i actually do prefer Android, because the bigger competition (in the end, Apple only competes with Apple) - Android phones innovate a lot more in terms of looks (also other things, but i dont care much for those)  Android phones NEED to stand out .. they came up with popping cameras (many brands), Swivelling screens (LG Wing), spinning cameras (Zenphone and A80), manual sliders (Honor and Xiaomi Mix), underscreen cameras (ZTE) et cetera. Apple plays it too safely .. there is no design innovation.  On the other hand - Apple continously uses better materials (on its expensive flagships) - with stainless steel and maybe slightly better glass (if that ceramic shield is noticably better than the Victus+ type)  My problem with Apple - aside from the lack of design innovation - is that it still claims to be the artists, "special" fringe, creator and so on phone .. for "people in the know" - when it has become the definition of mainstream.   As for my current decision ... i have a 22 ultra, because i actually really use the stylus a whole lot - and Apple does not have a Note type phone. The rest falls in place. Because the phone is Samsung, so are my tablets etc. (thank you ecosystem..)

Before I watch the video, I want to say what I think is the â€œbestâ€.   If you want a good camera that takes very consistent shots, iPhone is probably your best choice. You canâ€™t go wrong with a pixel either, but itâ€™s not quite as consistent.   If you want a good display, android. 4k 120 looks great on a phone, and many high end androids just have better and brighter screens.   If you want battery, iPhone again. The iPhoneâ€™s processor (A xx) is very power efficient when compared to android chips. The software optimization, and integration with the processor is unmatched.   If you want performance, iPhone wins again, in most circumstances. Apple so far has been able to produce a phone that doesnâ€™t get very hot, even under pretty heavy workloads. Android phones probably have a faster chip, but they have to be held back because of thermals.   If you are going budget, android. There are many budget android phones, with very respectable specs. The only big downsides are usually the camera, and built in ads which can usually be turned off somehow.
